DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF FORMER SENATOR J. B. KEEFFE

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death of former Senator James Bernard Keeffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 15 May 1988, of James Bernard Keeffe, senator for the State of Queensland from 1965 to 1983, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Jim Keeffe was born at Atherton in north Queensland on 20 August 1919. He left school at 13 to work as a farm hand. At the age of 20 he joined the Citizen Military Forces, transferring to the 2nd Australian Imperial Force in the dark days of 1942. He served in Australia, Papua-New Guinea and the Solomon Islands and because of the effect of war wounds was discharged on 27 October 1945 at the rank of sergeant.

Jim Keeffe served the Australian Labor Party (ALP) for more than 50 years in administrative roles. He was an organiser from 1956 to 1960, Secretary of the Queensland branch of the Labor Party from 1960 to 1965 and President of the National Executive from 1962 to 1970. He was elected to the Senate for Queensland in 1964, his term beginning on 1 July 1965. He was subsequently re-elected in 1970, 1974, 1975 and 1980. He retired in 1983. During his 18 years as a senator he served on various parliamentary committees. He also served as Senate Opposition Deputy Leader, shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and shadow Minister for Northern Australia.

One always has mixed feelings about one's colleagues in this place, but I always remember Jim Keeffe as a somewhat tireless debater on issues which were close to his heart. In those days I used to keep a sort of little black book of people who spoke at length on the adjournment and I must say that his name was always in it. He never gave up in pursuing points which he wanted to make in the Senate.

Jim Keeffe was appointed a parliamentary representative on the Council of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies from November 1967 to March 1976. He was a tireless campaigner for Aboriginal land rights and is widely remembered for fostering debate on this important issue throughout his public life. He was a founding member of the ALP Young Labor Association and was also prominent in promoting the full range of peace and environmental issues about which he was very concerned. He remained active in these matters until his death.

I suppose that Jim Keeffe, as a Queensland senator, will best be remembered for his tireless work for Aboriginal causes and also his tireless work for the less fortunate people of Townsville generally. His office there was something of a mecca, in a sense a branch office of the Department of Social Security, for all those people who had problems of one kind or another. In his home city of Townsville and in north Queensland he will be remembered particularly for his compassion and concern for the less fortunate.

Jim Keeffe was also a loyal and tireless worker for his Party and his country and was a respected member of the Senate. It was nice to see him here last week, with his two young daughters, for the opening of the new Parliament House. Obviously he was pleased to be seeing old colleagues and was enjoying the two or three days that he spent here. On behalf of the Government I extend to his family our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

In any event, his interest continued and I had a great deal to do with him, particularly over the period when I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and subsequently Minister for Social Security.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth recording that there were two sides to the late Jim Keeffe. He put his views with very great vigour and, sometimes, considerable heat. I found a very different character dealing with him outside the chamber. I found him very reasonable and helpful. He was always deeply concerned about his constituents. He brought many individual cases to me both with respect to Aboriginal Australians and, as the Leader of the Government has said, simply people in his electorate who were having difficulties of one sort or another. Some senators are said not to do very much electorate work, but I think that one could say that Jim Keeffe had a very large electorate practice which he pursued with great vigour. I was always very impressed by the sincerity of his concern for his constituents. I developed a very warm regard and affection for him because of that out of chamber contact which I am sure I would never have had had the contact been restricted to debate in this place.

It was said by the Leader of the Government that he was a tireless campaigner for Aboriginal land rights. I suppose that this is an area in which I would have joined him in debate right to the end because the pursuit of national land rights which developed during that late 1970s period was something which I think has caused enormous difficulties between the parties in this place and, indeed, in the community. As the Leader of the Government said, he left school at 13 years of age. The record shows that he did a good deal of subsequent study by correspondence. He worked as a farm labourer and as a public servant. He took a rehabilitation course in cooping after the Second World War and promptly became the State Secretary and the court advocate of the coopers union. He had a varied Labor career-one which, I am sure, was of very great value to him when he came to this place.

I think it should be acknowledged also that, as with so many of his generation, he saw war service. He was retired from the Services because of war wounds. I think that his service to Australia in that regard should also be acknowledged with some gratitude. I think it can be said that with the death of Jim Keeffe a very traditional Labor man has been lost. He was a man who, I think, certainly never lost touch with the grassroots of his Party. He was a man who worked assiduously among the people of Queensland whom he represented. Whilst he was, I think, to the left of the Australian Labor Party and, hence, often a very vigorous and noisy opponent of those of us on the other side of politics, he was a very worthy adversary. I am very sad at his death. On behalf of the Opposition I express my sympathy to his family who, I am sure, feel very great sorrow at having lost a very fine man.

SPEECH.PARA: I first met Jim Keeffe when he was Acting President of the Party-he was subsequently confirmed in the role of President-and we were having some difficulties. Of course, such problems are fairly synonymous with political parties today. In that capacity he was clearly able to distinguish between right and wrong in terms of the way in which the Party should operate and its members should work in pursuance of the objectives of the Party.

I found Jim Keeffe to be a very sociable and likeable person. He was a person who did not mince words in taking up causes. He expressed himself in a very passionate way on a whole range of issues-issues which were not so popular in the 1960s and 1970s but which have become much more acceptable in terms of community standards in the 1980s. I refer, of course, to his very active participation in the peace and disarmament movement and in the civil rights movement. Reference has already been made to his involvement in the anti-Vietnam war movement and his taking up of environment protection issues. Reference has been made to Jim Keeffe's devotion to the cause of the Aborigines. I think one could say that he was probably the most passionate defender in this place of their rights. He took up Aboriginal issues following the acceptance by the Australian people of a referendum in the 1960s which acknowledged the need to recognise the debt we owed to Aborigines and to take such legislative steps as were necessary to redress the wrongs and deficiencies of past eras.

I am attracted to what Senator Haines said about Jim Keeffe being part of the old school. Whilst he was part of the old school and part of the traditional base of my Party, I think his great strength lay in the fact that he was also very contemporary. He was able to appreciate and to be associated with the changes that were taking place in our society. I think that is a characteristic from which we could all learn.

Jim Keeffe was regarded in this place as a person who was very dogged in his contributions to debates. He was fiercely independent and was often regarded by some as being very tiresome when he pursued issues in a debate, but that was the way in which Jim Keeffe took up and defended a cause according to his philosophical position. To that extent, I suppose one could say that he became somewhat controversial. I know that I can say without doubt that in that process he did not incur any enmity. In fact, he won the respect of whatever government was in office at the time and the then Opposition.

From 1972 to 1975 Jim Keeffe was part of the first Labor Government in 20 years. Unfortunately, he was not able to be part of the first Hawke Government because he was an immediate casualty of the double dissolution that took place in 1983. He never failed to express himself against any form of racism. It took a great deal of courage and integrity to do that in Townsville, where perhaps examples of racism are found more often than one would wish to find in any part of Australia. At all times Jim Keeffe was an active supporter of the democratic socialist objectives of the Labor Party. He enjoyed membership of the Party for some 50 years. To the extent that he and I shared similar views on many issues a friendship developed beyond just the political norm.

Reference should be made to the fact that he was called up in the militia at the outbreak of the war. He became a member of the Australian Imperial Force and served in the South Pacific zone with the infantry during the 1942-45 period. He became a member of the Returned Services League (RSL). There he applied himself to the same extent as he did in this place. Perhaps we accepted his strongly expressed views, but in some cases he was not very popular in the RSL, particularly in some of its sectors. He was discharged as a result of being wounded in World War II. Being the sort of person he was, he decided to take advantage of the Commonwealth reconstruction training scheme. He enjoyed a short period in business activities and subsequently became a union official for two unions, the coopers union and the plumbers union. For nine years he served in that capacity on the industrial side of the Labor movement.

He was then appointed as an organiser of the Queensland branch of the Australian Labor Party and became the Secretary of that organisation, which he served for some 10 years. His public office activities were in both the industrial and political movements and then here in public office as a senator for 18 years.

The Aboriginal people have lost a very dear friend and defender of their views. He was a fervent campaigner for their interests, not only in respect of land rights. I recall my visit as a Minister to Townsville when the Hawke Government decided to recognise the inequalities in the treatment of the Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. When I arrived there on a visit I was requested to see Jim Keeffe with a delegation of Torres Strait Islanders. The decision of the Government meant that there was now a recognition that during World War II they had been paid a very small allowance as a wage. The Government decided to rectify that matter and remove all the discriminatory actions that had been taken during World War II.

Jim, on that occasion, as on many other occasions, took the necessary steps to acquaint the Torres Strait Islanders of what was available to them as a result of parliamentary decisions. I met a delegation which was able to present the views of those Torres Strait Islanders who might not otherwise have known of the decisions this Parliament had taken in that year's Budget. He loved his country and his Party and he certainly loved the Australian people. He was a very strong advocate for north Queensland. He taught me that the people of north Queensland regarded Canberra almost as another country. I also found in discussions with him that those people also regarded Brisbane in the same way. He was always able to show an essential objectivity in matters.

So, despite the fact that he pursued a controversial career and took up causes which often were not understood at the time he became their advocate, he lived to see the time when not only did the Australian Labor Party accept the advanced views that he held, but even this Parliament established organisations on an all-party basis to deal with peace and disarmament. To that extent Jim was a pioneer. On behalf of many of his former comrades, as well as those here who served such a short period with him, I say how much we regret his passing and how much we want to pass on our condolences to the remaining members of his family. I renewed my acquaintance with him last Monday. As has been referred to by other speakers, he brought his daughter here so that she might understand the importance of the parliamentary process. The great thing about Jim was that not only did he support the parliamentary process but also he believed in the extra-parliamentary activity of which he was one of the best advocates.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled. The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide independent radio and television service.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Regulations and Ordinances Committee is corresponding with Ministers about various items of delegated legislation to ensure that the Committee's principles have been complied with. Export Control (Fish) Orders as amended (Amendment), as contained in Export Control Orders No. 2 of 1988, and made under the Export Control (Orders) Regulations, made under the Export Control Act 1982.

The Committee is examining the practice in delegated legislation of incorporating into the legislation other non-legislative documents, like guidelines, methods or standards, which by virtue of incorporation, become themselves legislative in effect. The incorporation of ``existing'' documents and ``future'' documents (i.e. existing documents as amended ``from time to time'') can be subject to different legal rules which must be observed. The incorporated documents become a species of sub-delegated legislation often made by persons and bodies other than the delegated law-maker envisaged by Parliament when passing the enabling Bill. As such they should be subject to some form of parliamentary scrutiny. The Committee is seeking advice on these issues from the Minister for Resources, Senator the Hon. Peter Cook. The Committee is also examining a legal issue concerning the Secretary's power to approve certain sampling methods and fish ingredients which may be legislative and not merely administrative in character. Meat Inspection (Victoria) Orders as contained in Meat Inspection Orders No. 1 of 1988, made under the Meat Inspection (orders) Regulations, made under the Meat Inspection Act 1983.

2. Animal Welfare: Dolphins and Whales in Captivity

Since 1979 the Commonwealth Government has adopted a policy of protection for all cetaceans in the waters of the Australian Fishing Zone. Through its membership of the International Whaling Commission (IWC), Australia has played a leading role in efforts to ban commercial whaling worldwide. In 1982 the IWC agreed to a moratorium on commercial whaling to commence in the pelagic season of 1985-86 and the coastal season of 1986. Australia has also sought to reduce cruelty associated with whaling operations.
As most of the Senate Committee's recommendations affected State and Territory responsibilities the Commonwealth sought the views of the States and the Northern Territory.

State and Northern Territory legislation protects cetaceans to varying degrees: Victoria has legislated in line with the Committee's recommendations; New South Wales legislation protects all marine mammals and the capture and display of marine mammals is regulated; Queensland legislation defines cetaceans as `fish' and includes them on the list of protected species. Capture and keeping of cetacea for display purposes is allowed under permit from the Minister; Tasmanian legislation at present protects only small species of toothed whales; South Australian and Western legislation protects all cetaceans and prohibits their capture for display purposes except under permit; Northern Territory legislation presently protects all cetaceans.

Three of the recommendations relate wholly or in part to areas of Commonwealth responsibility. Under the Whale Protection Act 1980 the killing, injuring, taking or interfering with cetaceans is prohibited in Australian waters, excluding the coastal waters of States and the Northern Territory. The Act also prohibits such actions by Australians anywhere in the world.

In paragraph 8.9 the Committee recommends inter alia, that no permits be issued for the capture of cetaceans in Australian Commonwealth waters. It further recommends that importation of cetaceans from overseas be banned.

Section 11 of the Whale Protection Act 1980 provides that the Minister may, in his discretion, grant a permit to take cetaceans for live display or kill or take cetaceans for scientific or educational purposes. Only one application for a permit to capture cetaceans in Commonwealth waters has been received and no permits have been issued since the Whale Protection Act 1980 came into force.

The Act comprehends the possibility of future captures as limited circumstances may arise in which the live capture of cetaceans may be warranted, for example if there was a need for research because of a threat to the health of wild dolphin populations.

With regard to the importation of cetaceans from overseas, the Government already has in place, under the provisions of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982, legislation which imposes stringent restrictions on the importation of live cetaceans.

In paragraph 8.15 the Committee recommends that national standards for the maintenance and care of captive cetaceans be drawn up which would include standards for assessments of financial viability, natural display and educational and research components of captive cetacean display as well as covering all aspects of maintenance, handling and care of captive cetaceans.

The Commonwealth, through the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, will continue to co-operate with the relevant State Governments in developing national standards but the Commonwealth does not believe that such standards should necessarily include assessment of the financial viability of oceanaria.

In paragraph 8.20 the Committee recommends that a national advisory body be established comprising representatives from Federal and State Government authorities, non-government organisations and oceanaria which would advise the Federal and State Governments on matters relating to cetaceans, both captive and in the wild, and to encourage and monitor research in this area. Existing bodies such as the ANPWS and the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers already provide opportunities to discuss such issues. In addition, meetings with non-government organisations are held to discuss the International Whaling Commission and national cetacean issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade advise the Senate of action taken by the Government today in response to the situation in Vanuatu?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was extensive rioting by about 2,000 people in the capital of Vila yesterday in connection with what appears to be a long-running land dispute in Vanuatu. Reports indicate that one person was killed, a number were injured and considerable property damage was sustained in the capital. In a city with a population of fewer than 20,000, it is clear that these disturbances have been serious, including, as they did, an attempted attack on Prime Minister Lini's residence. As the Australian Prime Minister told the House of Representatives this afternoon, last night the Vanuatu Government issued an urgent request to the Australian Government to provide additional riot control equipment to the Vanuatu police in case there are further disturbances. A similar request was made to the New Zealand Government.

ANSWER.PARA: After speaking personally to Prime Minister Lini and in consultation with the Minister for Defence and the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Prime Minister decided that it was important for Australia to respond promptly and positively to the request, coming as it did from the duly elected government of a friendly South Pacific neighbour facing a very significant problem of law and order. The Government has made clear to the Vanuatu Government that the equipment and material are being provided on the basis that they are for containment of the situation and that any use of them should be in that context-that is, used only to the extent necessary to restore order and with all due concern to minimise injury. Since the request strongly emphasised the urgency of the situation, the Government moved quickly to make the necessary arrangements. This morning a Royal Australian Air Force Hercules flew to Vila carrying gas masks, tear gas canisters and tear gas launchers. This is standard police riot control material and equipment of the kind held by Australian police forces. The Government has remained in very close contact with the New Zealand Government on the situation. In response to the request for assistance from Vanuatu, the New Zealand Government will be providing equipment and material complementary to the supplies that we are sending. Prime Minister Lange told Prime Minister Hawke today that he expected a New Zealand aircraft to depart for Vanuatu later this afternoon.

Finally, let me say that I believe honourable senators will share the Government's sincere hope that the equipment which we have supplied to the Vanuatu authorities will not in the event be required. I am pleased to be able to report that, according to the most recent information available, the situation today in Vila appears to have quietened, but it does remain tense. The final matter is that of Australians in Vanuatu. I advise the Senate that our High Commission has made extensive inquiries of Australians in Vila, of whom I understand there are some 700 or so, and has reported that all Australians contacted are safe.

Is the Minister aware that certain Australian companies have made special issues of one cent paid shares to their senior executives and have then made issues of bonus shares to the holders of those one cent paid shares on a basis exactly equivalent to the issue of bonus shares to the holders of normal fully paid shares? Can the Minister give the Senate an assurance that the Government's tax reforms have meant that income received by senior executives under this type of arrangement is taxed appropriately? What tax would have been paid on such income had this Government not introduced a capital gains tax? Does the Minister believe it is possible to `Fosterise' the taxation system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that certain Australian companies have made an issue of shares paid up to one cent and then issued bonuses on them. In September last year Elders Resources made a bonus share issue and this was referred to by Terry McCrann, a finance journalist who, as I have stated before, I am sure would be offended if anyone described him as a friend of the Australian Labor Party. Mr McCrann wrote in the Herald on 31 December about the Elders Resources issue:

ANSWER.PARA: The executives held 5.83 million Elders Resources shares paid to just 1c each (aggregate cost thus of just $58,300).
As well, those 1c paid shares had delivered the executives something like 2.2 million free fully-paid shares from two Elders Resources bonus issues in the past year.

Indeed, the promised profit was made all the greater by a fortuitous issue by Elders Resources of 3.125 million 1c paid shares in the September quarter. Fortuitous, because the timing of that issue rendered the recipient(s?) eligible to participate in the one-for-three bonus issue declared by Elders Resources on September 23 with its profit announcement.

That issue of 1c paid shares (total cost $31,250) effectively carried with it therefore more than one million free fully-paid shares-which only a few months later, and post-crash, can be sold to NZFP-
for more than $2.5 million. Better than an evening locked in a padded cell with Mark Jackson.

I can assure the Senate that under the present taxation arrangements a proper amount of tax would be levied on the profit from that share transaction. Where bonus shares with a par value of 50c are distributed, that 50c is treated as a dividend. If it is unfranked, the recipient has to pay the tax on it; if it is franked, the company, of course, has already paid the tax on it. Where such a share is sold at a price above 50c, the seller is liable for capital gains taxation on the capital gain in the standard way.

It is well known, of course, that a senior executive of Elders Resources Ltd-indeed, I think its Chairman-has been calling for the abolition of the capital gains tax. He also happens to be President of the Liberal Party of Australia. Leaving aside the morality of the issues themselves by the people who are managing these companies, such gains would remain tax free if the present Government's capital gains tax policy were to be abolished. The one exception, of course, is shares that would have had to be held for 12 months under the pre-existing policy because section 26aaa would otherwise have caught them.

Since then, it has been proposed by the Opposition that a capital gains tax be effectively phased out over five years. So, in the past all that Mr Elliott and his mates, who have cleaned up millions over the last few years at the expense of other shareholders in Elders and associated companies, had to do was wait and hold shares for 12 months. At present, under this Government's policy, they have to pay capital gains tax on them. All they would have to do, if the Opposition were ever elected and enacted its policy, would be to hang on to their shares for five years and pay no capital gains tax at all. This is no doubt a major reason why the Opposition has adopted that policy. In any period in that five-year holding period, the capital gains tax liability under the Opposition's proposal would decline by 20 per cent for each year the shares were held. I guess this helps to explain why Mr Elliott seems to have shelved his parliamentary ambition-he can get his policy implemented through the existing Liberal Party leadership anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the Aboriginal Development Commission and to last Friday's media release by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I ask: First, does the action of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in dismissing eight of the 10 commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission mean that the Government will tolerate as representatives of Aboriginal Australians only people who go along unquestionably with its discredited policies? Secondly, has the Government sought undertakings from the new appointees announced by the Minister to cooperate fully with the restructuring of the administration of Aboriginal affairs? Finally, is the Minister aware that Mr Ken Colbung, Chairman of the Western Australian Aboriginal Advisory Committee, has described the eight appointees as `scabs' both to their own people and in terms of trade union principle? Is there any reason to doubt Mr Colbung's view that the commissioners were sacked by Mr Hand because, as Mr Colbung said, `they dared to hold an opinion different to his' and that this action does not augur well if the proposed new body is created under the direct control of the Minister?

—I do not accept some of the assumptions and implications in the question. I certainly do not agree with some of the comments that the honourable senator attributed to another person in relation to the dismissal by the Minister of certain part time commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission. In particular, I refute any suggestion that the Minister has attempted to put in place a body which is not going to exercise the proper independence which it should if it is to fulfil its responsibilities and duties under the new arrangements envisaged by the Minister. In relation to this matter of the dismissals, honourable senators will be aware that, as I understand it, there is a matter before the Federal Court of Australia. The part time commissioners who have been sacked have obtained an injunction restraining the Minister from carrying this dismissal into full effect. Until that matter is resolved in the Federal Court, it should not be canvassed in this chamber as it might otherwise be. The part time commissioners are seeking a ruling on the legality of the dismissals.

—I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate the point that the matter is being pursued in the courts but, in the light of the Minister's first response this afternoon, I ask him: Why did the Minister sack the eight commissioners if the reason was that of the independent representation of the Aboriginal people of Australia?

—As I understand it, the Minister dismissed the eight part time commissioners because of their refusal to participate in the implementation of government policy. But these matters will be subject to action in the courts and I really believe that this is not a proper forum in which to canvass them.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to an article in today's Brisbane Courier-Mail reporting the Queensland Premier's claims that proposed Federal cutbacks in State grants mean that his Budget review committee has begun a tough assessment of options and that new taxes are being considered for Mr Ahern's first State Budget to be brought down in August. How much of Queensland's financial problems are not related to the fact that Mr Ahern did not get everything he wanted at last week's Premiers Conference? Finally, is it the Commonwealth's responsibility to bail out the Queensland Government in respect of these financial difficulties?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second part of the question referred to the extent to which Queensland's economic problems are related to the fact that Mr Ahern did not get his own way at the Premiers Conference last week. If Mr Ahern could tap into an unlimited supply of free money from the Commonwealth Government, undoubtedly that would overcome Queensland's economic problems-leaving aside what that would do to the rest of Australia. The fact is that Queensland had very severe economic problems for a considerable period before last week's Premiers Conference. Honourable senators may recall that on 9 September I tabled a draft submission to be presented to the Queensland Cabinet, which was signed by the Under Treasurer, which revealed among other things that the State was showing prospective deficits of-and I am using round figures-$160m next year and $215m the following year. Even that was based on some pretty heroic assumptions, such as no growth in the number of public servants; no new programs, tax concessions, special major projects or work programs; no major national disaster or strikes; no further cuts in Commonwealth funding; and no adverse results of the Commonwealth Grants Commission's relativity review. It was prepared on the basis of a complete escape from the facts of life.

ANSWER.PARA: The only comparable advice on a government's Budget position, which has been so seriously mismanaged except on a larger scale, is the advice prepared by Senator Stone in 1983 in his capacity as Secretary to the Treasury, advice prepared for the Liberal-National Party coalition Government had it been returned to office. Senator Stone, among other things, said:
When the estimated cost in 1983-84 of the new policy proposals announced in the policy speech is added, the prospect is for a Budget deficit of almost $10 billion.
A Budget deficit of almost $10 billion, wrote Senator Stone as Secretary to the Treasury. He continued:
Such a deficit would be equivalent to 5 1/2 per cent of projected gross domestic product, the highest in Australian post-war history.
There were many other equally important passages in Senator Stone's paper, one of which is:
First, the magnitude of the fiscal imbalance is unprecedented in Australia during peace time, as is the level of Government spending.

The sort of financial shambles which the coalition Government left behind it when it was ignominiously kicked out of office in March 1983 is comparable to the financial shambles which exists in Queensland now and which existed in Queensland long before the Premiers Conference.

If Queensland really wants to do something to improve its financial position and also, as many States have argued, to eliminate duplications by Commonwealth and State governments of essentially the same activity, I suggest that it flog off its Agent-General's Office in the Strand in London-an example that the rest of the States might well take up. Collectively, they would probably get $100m for the properties that they hold there, which would help them out with their Budgets and which would also remove the unnecessary duplication of efforts already made by the Commonwealth Government on behalf of the nation as a whole.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Justice. It follows the question asked by Senator Hill and relates to the criticism of the National Crime Authority's conduct of the investigation which led to the recent dismissal of charges against Mr Al Grassby and the Minister's statement that he has called for a transcript of the remarks. Is the Minister aware that this is not the first such case to arise? In particular, is the Minister aware that on 11 March 1988 Stipendiary Magistrate Mr C. A. Johansen dismissed conspiracy charges in South Australia against the suspended Assistant Police Commissioner (Crime), Mr Kevin Harvey, and two others? Is the Minister aware that the charges were laid after investigations by the National Crime Authority and that the magistrate said that the prosecution case would never have succeeded before a jury and that it was full of weaknesses? He said:

QUESTION.PARA: The charge could not be proved beyond reasonable doubt to a properly instructed and reasonable jury.

Did the Minister investigate how an NCA case could have been pursued before the courts with such obvious weaknesses? Was the Minister concerned at the loss of public support of the NCA which can follow from such judicial comments and indeed results? What did the Minister do about that case?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the case in South Australia where a charge brought against a police officer was dismissed. Of course, that is the whole purpose of committal proceedings, namely, to sort out those matters which, in the opinion of the magistrate, would not be likely to result in a properly instructed jury presented with all the facts finding a case proved beyond reasonable doubt. Indeed, that is one of the great strengths of our legal system.
—You would expect it to occur on odd occasions but it is a different story when we are having a sequence of events.

—I was just about to say that a strength of our system is that committal proceedings, presided over by a magistrate, act as a sifting process. On occasion one would expect those committal proceedings to result in the accused walking away with the presumption of innocence vindicated. I also made the point in response to Senator Hill's question that one must bear in mind that, whilst the National Crime Authority carries out investigations and puts together a brief of evidence, the NCA itself does not decide that a prosecution should take place. There is interposed after that the independent discretion of the prosecuting authority in the State concerned-and indeed no doubt that was the case in South Australia. So, there are various stages which are appropriate and which were followed in the case referred to.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of the impact of these cases on the general reputation of the National Crime Authority, I think that that is a matter for judgment, and I would expect-although naturally I am not privy to this-that the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority would have had an opportunity to canvass these matters, certainly in relation to the matter of 11 March, with the National Crime Authority when it was carrying out its assessment of the Authority's effectiveness and, indeed, making a judgment as to its proper discharge of the role granted to it under legislation of this Parliament. I would imagine that, when he goes to the intergovernmental committee meeting in Brisbane next Thursday week, the Attorney-General will be canvassing the whole history of the successes or otherwise of those matters that have been brought before courts as a result of National Crime Authority investigations and compilings of briefs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the Minister for Justice that I asked him, with respect to the case dealt with by Stipendiary Magistrate Johansen, whether he took any action following that case. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that he has said this afternoon that he has called for a transcript in a case where the magistrate said that it was appalling that there was no attempt by the National Crime Authority to corroborate the evidence of a perjurer, drug dealer and criminal, and the fact that the South Australian case was said to have been fatally flawed by the evidence of the prosecution's principal witness, who was shown to be inconsistent and unreliable. I ask the Minister again: Was any action taken by him as Minister to investigate that case to see whether there was in fact an appropriate contribution by the National Crime Authority, or is this a matter that he has simply let go over the shoulder?

—I did not make a particular request for details of the action of the National Crime Authority in relation to that matter, and I will inquire of the Attorney-General whether he made any such inquiry. I do not believe that it is fair to characterise the Government's attitude as one of indifference or of allowing these matters to pass by. One was aware of it, and indeed the best opportunity for carrying out our responsibilities in relation to this matter will be presented at the intergovernmental committee meeting of Ministers next Thursday week, when I can assure the honourable senator these matters will be canvassed with all Ministers and members of the National Crime Authority.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources. I refer to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 29 April 1988 in which the Minister is reported to have said that the Government's energy policies are clearly working. Can the Minister indicate to the Senate the Government's energy policies and identify the evidence on which he based his statement that the Government's energy policies are clearly working?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that article appeared in the paper on the day that it did because it followed the tabling in this chamber by me of Energy 2000, the Government's document setting out its audit of Australia's total energy resources, and also setting out a series of proposals on policy options for the Government between now and the end of this century. I believe that that is a seminal reference document on this subject and provides the answer to the first part of the question.

ANSWER.PARA: However, there has been some public debate about the Government's approach to seeking to obtain security of supply for oil resources in Australia rather than pursuing an illusion of energy self-sufficiency through trying to generate self-sufficiency in petroleum. As a country of medium prospectivity and with all the other economic inputs, such as the price of a barrel of oil and so on, it would be an illusion to chase that kind of energy self-sufficiency objective.

In order to give a fuller answer to the Senate on our energy trade balance, I point out that the Energy 2000 policy statement reports that, between now and the end of this century, if we net out the positive contribution that energy exports will make by reducing them by the amount that it will cost us as a country to import oil, energy will contribute $60 billion to Australia's balance of payments account. That is made up of $15 billion from liquefied natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas exports; about $30 billion from steaming coal exports; about $40 billion from coke and coal; and $9 billion from exports of uranium. On the general aspect of how we are travelling in terms of investment--

TALK.START.PARA: —How many mines will that $9 billion come from?

—It needs to come from only two mines, because they have a capacity to ratchet up their production if necessary, if there is a bigger demand than anticipated. That capacity is well understood and known by our client countries.
—But we could sell even more.

—The existing capacity will allow us to sell whatever is required. I turn now to some major announcements by energy companies in Australia which I think give some degree of confidence to the Government that its policy settings are correct. Only recently the Shell company announced an investment program of $2.6 billion covering all its activities in Australia. That is a major investment in extra refining capacity and distribution, as well as an investment of $1 billion in production and exploration by that company in the search for and exploitation of oil resources in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: Recently the World Board of the Texaco Oil Development Company visited Australia and in discussions its Vice-President, Mr Earle L. Johnson, indicated that in that company's view Australia is a country in which Texaco wishes to increase its investment by becoming an active bidder for exploration acreage here. He also said that he thought that our tax regime was benign compared with countries similar to Australia. The Bureau of Mineral Resources will spend $6m over the next five years on seismic surveys to gauge the petroleum and mineral potential of the Canning Basin in Western Australia. That will enable the Government to consider further releases of exploration acreage in that area, it will provide us with a better seismic profile of the geology of that region and it will enable us to reassess our geological expectations of oil discovery.

Further, the Treasurer's decision in January to deregulate foreign investment in offshore oil production, in what has become known as the Saladin or Wapet-West Australian Petroleum Pty Ltd-decision I think is attracting a great deal more overseas interest and investment in Australia. Just recently the North West Shelf project announced that it has let contracts in Australia worth over $70m for four designs for the Goodwyn platform in anticipation of being able to give the next phase, the export phase, of that project the go-ahead early next year. Interestingly, those contracts went mainly to Australian companies. Only one, for a minor design component of a major aspect of the project, went overseas-to San Francisco-and, if that is proved up, the work will be done here in Australia. In terms of general investment and commentary by Australian and overseas countries on the energy profile for this country, it is indeed very comforting from the Government's point of view.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Justice. I refer him to reports last week and at the weekend about grave new allegations of bribery and cover-up associated with the notorious Enmore conspiracy case and the so-called Sydney Love Boat affair. In particular, I refer to the report that two senior Australian Labor Party (ALP) members of Federal Parliament have been named in a police report as accomplices in a $150,000 cover-up attempt. Is the National Crime Authority (NCA) still investigating, as it reportedly was doing in November 1986, the alleged payments to Mr Joe Meissner-a member of the ALP-to withdraw from sale a package of documents, tapes and photographs arising out of the Enmore case? Or has the Enmore-Love Boat scandal been declared off limits for the NCA because of the reported involvement of the two senior ALP figures concerned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refute absolutely any assertion made by Senator Michael Baume that the National Crime Authority could be frightened off anything properly within the scope of a reference or indeed that could be undertaken in pursuit of its general powers of investigation as a result of being warned off for some political reason or some barrier being raised to its operations because some undue political influence was brought to bear. That is totally unthinkable for anyone who knows the character of the various NCA members and in particular Mr Justice Stewart. I think even those members of the Opposition who sit on the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority would join with me in refuting any inference whatsoever that they could be dissuaded through political pressure from carrying out an investigation into a matter properly within their province.

ANSWER.PARA: Indeed, knowing Mr Justice Stewart as I do, it would probably redouble his efforts. So I completely refute the colouring and tainting in the question raised by Senator Baume. As to the question of whether any particular investigation is being conducted at the moment, I take that on notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his clarifying statement but I ask him to perhaps clarify a little more. Can the Minister give an unequivocal assurance that all relevant Federal authorities will cooperate fully with any inquiry by the New South Wales Government's Independent Commission Against Corruption into this matter.

—Honourable senators will be aware that, in relation to the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, the various Federal authorities-the Australian Federal Police and the National Crime Authority-not on my instructions but certainly with my encouragement, have aided Mr Fitzgerald in the conduct of that inquiry and have benefited it. I know that they would adopt this general principle in response to any proper request received by them from the properly constituted authority undertaking a proper inquiry. I support them in making independent decisions to help in any such investigation.
—No unequivocal assurance.
—Oh, fair go!

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training aware that there is widespread discrimination in Australia in the area of employment against the mature age unemployed? Is the Minister further aware that this form of discrimination is particularly likely to disadvantage people who are at risk to other forms of discrimination, such as mature age unemployed people of ethnic origin, mature age unemployed women, mature age unemployed Aboriginal people and mature age unemployed disabled people? What steps does the Government plan to take to counter this discrimination and to give the mature age unemployed equality of opportunity on merit in the area of employment? Given that age discrimination is a very significant form of discrimination in Australia not so far covered by specific legislation, does the Government intend to amend existing legislation or introduce new legislation to provide penalties for discrimination against individuals solely on the ground of age?

—Essentially, I have been asked whether the Government intends to legislate for a perfect world. The answer is: Not to my knowledge because I do not know how one could enforce such legislation anyway let alone, to be more specific, prove that there had been discrimination on the ground of age against somebody seeking employment. I remind Senator Jenkins and the rest of the Australian Democrats that the only long term cure to the problems she has allegedly identified is full employment. A return to full employment is the only real cure for the problems is that Senator Jenkins claims exist. I remind Senator Jenkins and the rest of the Democrats that, if they had their way, far from moving to full employment, we would undoubtedly have higher unemployment because of their propensity to want to close down half the industries in the country which can pay their way.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It refers to an article in the Brisbane Sun newspaper on 5 May 1988 which indicated that a group of Japanese performers in Brisbane for World Expo 88 bought a house for $350,000. Do Treasury guidelines prevent the purchase of residential property by non-Australians except in special circumstances and, if so, what are those circumstances? Have the details of this particular purchase been investigated and will it be allowed to proceed? If the sale is contrary to Government guidelines, will any action be taken against the real estate agent who arranged the sale?

—Last September the foreign investment guidelines for the purchase of residential property by foreigners were changed. There are three special categories of exemption from that restriction. The first is for Australian citizens resident abroad, the second is for intending migrants who have received approval to take up permanent residence in Australia and the third category is for foreign companies seeking accommodation for their senior executives while they are resident in Australia. I have seen the article to which Senator Colston refers and it seems to me that the particular purchase fits into the last of those three categories. I will refer the article to the Treasurer's office for confirmation that this is indeed the case and for any other comments that the Treasurer wishes to make about Senator Colston's question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Justice to the decision made last week by the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) to issue a summons against the Secretary of the New South Wales Branch of the Australian Labor Party (ALP), Mr Stephen Loosley, for a breach of the Commonwealth Electoral Act for the non-disclosure of a $10,000 election campaign donation from Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd in 1987. I also refer the Minister to the Director's statement:

QUESTION.PARA: On the basis of the police report no charge against any other person is warranted.

Does the Minister recall that the donation was sent first to the then Federal President of the ALP and former member for Port Adelaide, Mr Mick Young, who initially explained the non-disclosure as `a fairly honest mistake'? Does he also recall that the Federal member for Eden-Monaro, Mr Jim Snow, received election campaign funds from the New South Wales Labor Party the same day as the Harris-Daishowa donation was acknowledged by the ALP? I ask: In view of these involvements by Mr Young and Mr Snow, has the Minister satisfied himself that no charge against any other person is warranted? Now that the DPP has made his decision, will the Minister table the Australian Federal Police report on which this claim is based?

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is no, I do not intend to substitute myself for the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Ian Temby, who, on the basis of the authority conferred on him by this Parliament, has come to a decision based on his fair reading of the Australian Federal Police report. The idea that I might surmise this or that or that Senator Short should substitute himself for the Director of Public Prosecutions would, quite frankly, fill all ordinary citizens with horror. As an active working politician, I certainly do not intend to substitute myself for the independent statutory authority which this Parliament has established to make the decisions which Mr Temby has made. I am quite sure-in so far as Mr Temby has satisfied himself-that the decision that no particular charges be laid against any other person is utterly proper.

—Is the Minister for Consumer Affairs aware of newspaper reports that paint products containing high levels of lead are being imported? In view of their toxic potential, what action can be taken to reduce the hazards posed by such products?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the report to which Senator Zakharov refers appeared in the Melbourne Herald some time in the last couple of weeks. It referred to the importation of tubes of artists' supplies, the contents of which seem to be quite safe but the allegation is that the tubes themselves have a lead content of approximately 94 per cent. I understand the actual paint was and is non-toxic and does not present the same sorts of hazards to the users. Obviously in this instance the users on the whole would be young people. There is in fact an Australian standard which covers toys. That standard covers both the content of the toy and accessible coating material in respect of toys. In relation to this material, the standard is that a component of lead of not more than 0.25 per cent be allowed in the actual coating material. As a consequence, the allegations seem to indicate that there may in fact be a breach of that standard. I have asked the Office of Consumer Affairs to arrange for tests of those artists' supplies to ensure that the standard is not breached. In this context I should also say that the standard does have within it a criterion for assessment and determination of the level of lead in a product. It also has within it a criterion for determining whether that lead is accessible in the normal use, so I think that we have a pretty effective regime in terms of assessing the offensive material and whether it breaches the standard involved.

ANSWER.PARA: In going to the broader aspect of Senator Zakharov's question, I should mention that I have already asked the Office to inquire into the need for a mandatory safety standard covering children's paints and crayons in general because from time to time there seem to be particular problems in this area as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware that 9 June 60 years ago is the day when Sir Charles Kingsford Smith landed in Australia after his achievement of being the first pilot to fly across the Pacific Ocean? Is he also aware that special celebrations of this achievement are to be held in America? In view of the fact that Australia is such a large country and aviation plays a very important role for travel in it, not just for members of parliament throughout Australia who could hardly manage to carry out their duties without it, and the fact that Sir Charles Kingsford Smith was an Australian aviator, is the Government planning to give special recognition to this feat by `Smithy' 60 years ago? Could consideration be given to the issue of a special stamp to mark this very important occasion?

—I think it is a little late to get a special stamp organised, but I will certainly give consideration to some appropriate way of commemorating the flight in question which, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen rightly said, was a great occasion in the history of this country.

—My question is to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Does the Government endorse the reported claims made by Mr Paul Hogan that Australia cannot handle any more United States tourists?
—Handle them in what sense?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall ignore Senator Collins's interjection. I will allow him to tell the Senate how he handles United States tourists. I will not venture a comment as to how the rest of us might move forward. I turn to the remarks of Mr Hogan on the Barbara Walters show in the United States. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: I will still do another one or two-
referring to commercials for the Australian Government-

and I am sort of saying to sort of pull your heads in a little because we have all the tourists we can handle . . . Yeah, stay at home! Well it's getting close to that stage of doing a commercial saying look, come next year, there's no room for you at the moment.

All I can say is that there is still room at the inn. As far as I can read it, obviously Mr Hogan, in appearing on the Barbara Walters show, was engaging in the sort of humour which has made him famous. Apparently the reaction in the United States is to take it as part of Hogan's humour. Indeed, the reaction from the United States so far suggests that it has been excellent publicity for Australia, making it, once again, a sought-after destination. So I do not think that we will worry too much about it. Certainly, the travel industry in the United States seems to have the view that the interview will attract more tourists. Given that last year we had over 300,000 visitors from the United States, which was an increase of 26 per cent on the previous year, and that this year we expect more than 400,000, I believe that, once again, Hogan has done Australia a favour and we ought not to take this too seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Transport and Communications to the fact that Coolangatta Airport on the Gold Coast is one of the busiest in the country, with a flight path directly above densely populated suburbs. Is the Minister aware that Coolangatta Airport has no radar facilities and that traffic controllers use binoculars to sight and guide aircraft for landing and take-off manoeuvres? Is the Minister aware that because of the situation there was a recent near-miss at Coolangatta when a DC9 jet aborted a landing about 30 seconds before a 737 jet landed from the opposite end of the runway? Does the Minister intend to take action to equip Coolangatta Airport with a new aircraft control tower, radar equipment and an instrument landing system before there is a tragedy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was an occurrence on Friday, 6 May, at Coolangatta Airport involving two aircraft approaching the airport to land from opposite directions. Air traffic control was monitoring the situation at all times and was satisfied that full aircraft separation could be maintained throughout, and indeed that was the case, as a subsequent investigation by the Bureau of Air Safety has established. I am advised that, after consultation with air traffic control, the pilot of one aircraft elected to remain in the aerodrome circuit and to make another approach to land. When that decision was made, the other aircraft was still more than five nautical miles from the other end of the strip, so no breakdown of separation occurred of a kind that would have caused any alarm, or no breakdown of separation occurred in the sense that there was any variation from the minimum standards of horizontal and vertical separation that are required.

ANSWER.PARA: It is correct that Coolangatta Airport has no radar, but I am advised that that has no relevance to the particular occurrence to which Senator Sheil referred in his question. Brisbane radar provides service down to approximately 4,000 feet over Coolangatta from where aircraft are processed into the Coolangatta Airport traffic circuit. Separation of aircraft on the Coolangatta runway, including all take-off and landing clearances, is effected by visual means, as indeed it is at all controlled airports in Australia-for example, at Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne, Adelaide, and Perth. As I have already indicated, although the presence of radar is not relevant to this incident or occurrence to which Senator Sheil referred, I take the opportunity to advise the Senate that under the radar enhancement program currently in train, radar coverage down to ground level will be provided at Coolangatta by the early 1990s.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Home Affairs and follows an earlier question by Senator Short to the Minister for Justice. Can the Minister inform me how many cases of failing to disclose donations are currently being pursued by the Australian Electoral Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the moment, some 23 cases are being pursued by the Electoral Commission for the same offence as Mr Loosley has been summonsed on. One further case is being investigated of an individual who may or may not be charged in future with wilfully supplying false information to the Commission which, of course, is the major charge under the Act and involves a $10,000 fine. These investigations will not be attended by the same cheap publicity as has afflicted Mr Loosley, to the point where it is raised again today, prejudicing his chances of a fair defence in these matters.

ANSWER.PARA: We have said all along that the appropriate methods will be followed in these cases and they have been. It is a pity that the other side does not acknowledge that. We said that there would be no impediment to the police inquiry and there was none. We said that there would be no impediment to the Director of Public Prosecutions making up his mind on the evidence and recommending whether to charge or not. I could quite easily have got up in this chamber time and time again and raised the Carpentaria case in the Northern Territory, involving 29 times more money and with direct links to the Liberal and National parties in Queensland, or their combined name-the National-Liberal Party of Queensland. TALK.START.PARA: —Why haven't we done so?

When the police investigation is finalised, if there are charges they will go to the Director of Public Prosecutions. We will not see the Government putting out a Press release every second day proclaiming people's guilt, as Senator Short, Mr Reith and others have done. All they have done is show me that they are not really interested in the case, but in cheap political point scoring. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the procedures laid down by the resolutions of the Senate of 25 February 1987, Senator Walters, by letter dated 5 May 1988 and received by me on 10 May 1988, raised a matter of privilege. Under the Senate's resolutions I am required to determine whether a motion to refer the matter to the Senate Committee of Privileges should have precedence of other business, having regard to the following criteria:

INTERJECT.PARA: (a) the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate; and
(b) the existence of any remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt.

The essence of the matter raised by Senator Walters is an allegation that the Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material published a misleading account of the proceedings and report of that Committee.

The wilful publication of a misleading report of proceedings of a House or a committee is one of the categories of contempts identified in the Senate's resolutions of 25 February. Having regard to criterion (a), I think that the matter raised is capable of being treated by the Senate as a serious matter.

Having regard to criterion (b), however, I believe that there is an important consideration which dictates that I should not give precedence to a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee. The matter raised concerns a member of the House of Representatives. The only remedy for an alleged contempt by a member of that House is action by that House. The Senate cannot deal with it. It would be constitutionally wrong, in my view, for the Senate or its Privileges Committee even to attempt to consider the matter raised. For that reason I have determined that a motion on the matter should not have precedence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

Mr President, while I am naturally disappointed with your ruling that the chairman of a joint committee bears no responsibility to those members of that committee in this chamber, I accept your decision but believe that the Senate deserves an explanation of the reasons why I took the action I did. Following the tabling of the first volume of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material on 28 April this year I could not understand why it was that while the television reports of the recommendations of the Committee were correct-some of the members of that Committee indeed were able to be interviewed to give the correct version-every written report in the media was wrong. Most of the Committee's recommendations were unanimous. But the majority of the Committee voted against X-rated videos being retained in the Australian Capital Territory. I quote from the report when it discussed the new category of non-violent erotica (NVE) and the proposal that X-rated material should be included in that category. The report stated:

Rather than entrench this material into the community we recommend that the Commonwealth Government introduce substantive legislation to ensure that this material is refused classification for the purposes of the Commonwealth laws.

Very clearly the Committee itself chose to refuse classification for X-rated material. Again, when talking about X-classified material being included in the NVE classification, the majority of the Committee-in other words, the Committee-said:
The proposal runs counter to the overwhelming burden of evidence submitted to the Committee concerning the harmful effects of this material and is inconsistent with the finding of the Committee.

Mr President, as you can imagine, I was surprised, to say the last, when I read the next day headlines such as the examples I sent to you. One article in the Tasmanian Examiner was headed `Review on video nasties blasted', and stated:

A federal parliamentary committee on videos had ignored evidence that most children who came into contact with violent and sexually explicit material did so in their own home, it was claimed yesterday.

The Australian Council for Children's Film and Television's television officer Mrs Barbara Biggins said that in making recommendations on video classifications, film censorship and video displays the select committee had failed to remove violent material and sexually explicit videos from the home market.
Again, an Age editorial was headed `Pornographers get the green light'. We also had several other headlines in the Age. One article headed `Erotic videos get new rating' stated:
People who enjoy non-violent, sexually explicit videos might soon be allowed watch them, at least by the Federal Government.
After a three-year investigation, a joint parliamentary committee has recommended-but only by six to five-that sexually explicit videos be rated as NVE.

I could go on for a considerable time quoting newspaper headlines such as `Ban on hard-core video may go'. Of course, we then have the various letters written to the papers. Eventually the Australian newspaper in an article headed `Porn videos outcry grows', stated:
Dismay and disbelief can best describe the reaction of most Australians to the possible return of hard-core pornography to cinemas and video shops.

I received a considerable amount of mail, newsletters and Press releases from people who had read the reports in the newspapers and who believed that the majority of the Committee had recommended that X-rated videos should be retained. I was eventually handed a copy of the Press release of the Chairman of the Committee. I would like to quote from that because this is obviously where the confusion arose. The Chairman of the Committee, Dr Klugman, issued this Press release on 28 April. It said:
The report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material was tabled in Federal Parliament today.

The Committee recommends that a new category called NVE (non-violent erotica) be used in the classification of videos. The new category is to contain the material included in the current censorship classification X.

That is a complete falsehood. The Committee did not at any stage recommend that. (Quorum formed) The Committee did not recommend that at all; indeed, it recommended the opposite. The Press release went on:
Dr Klugman, Chairman of the Committee, said: `The label NVE will clearly identify the type of material included in the category-erotic, but containing no violence'.
`Many people are under the erroneous impression that videos given an X rating under the current censorship code may contain violence, child pornography and bestiality.'
This is not the case.
`It became evident to the Committee that a new category was necessary to reflect clearly the actual nature of the erotica allowed in the ACT and the Northern Territory,' he said.
Videos rated X by the Commonwealth Film Censorship Board are not currently available for hire from video outlets in any of the States.
Dr Klugman in his Press release then made a very erroneous and false statement:

The Committee, on balance, found that claims of harm from viewing sexually explicit material were not substantiated and therefore did not warrant the prohibition of such material. The question of a ban needed to be weighed against the rights of adults to see, hear and read what they wished, subject to safeguards for those under eighteen years of age. This view was not accepted by all members of the Committee, some of whom wished to prohibit the circulation of any video rated as X (or NVE, under the new proposal) by the Film Censorship Board.

To use the wording of the Standing Orders, I believe that the Chairman wilfully caused to be published false reports of the proceedings of our Committee. He has made a very deliberate misrepresentation. The Chairman has spoken in his Press release about the minority report to which he was a party, not of the majority report to which I was a party. I object very strongly to his Press release being put out. The Chairman went on in his Press release:
We have recommended that it be an offence for anyone to show a minor a video rated R or NVE without the consent of a parent or guardian.
The Press release then refers to the other recommendations-recommendations which were, of course, correct.

Because I really could not believe that anyone would so deliberately misrepresent the findings of a committee, I decided to write to the President, and I am sure the Senate would be interested in the letter I wrote. It reads:
Dear Mr President,
As Deputy Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, I am writing to you on a matter of Privilege in accordance with the Resolution of the Senate of the 25th February, 1988.
Following the tabling of the Report of that Committee, on 28th April, 1988 the Chairman put out the attached news release.
This is the news release that I have just read. My letter goes on:

In the second paragraph, Dr Klugman said `The new category is to contain the material included in the current censorship classification X'. This is not correct, in fact, the majority of the members of the Committee voted against current X classification videos being available under any heading.

Again, in the first paragraph of the second page, Dr Klugman says `The Committee, on balance, found that claims of harm from viewing sexually explicit material were not substantiated and therefore did not warrant the prohibition of such material'. This is totally incorrect. The Committee voted to ban x-rated sexually explicit material videos. As a result of the Chairman's press release, the reports in the major newspapers were incorrect, and I enclose examples for your information.

As Deputy Chairman of the Committee, I am very concerned that the Chairman so blatantly has misled the public about the recommendations of this Joint Committee, and believe it to be a breach of privilege of the Parliament.

I believe that the Chairman has wilfully and totally misled the media in the Press release. He has done it very deliberately and falsely and it is for these reasons that, as Deputy Chairman, I have taken this action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to speak on this matter; I was not aware that it was coming up and I regret I have not seen the Press release referred to. I do feel that this whole debate has got out of control. As a member of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, I can say to the Senate that opinions on controversial issues were very divided. In other words, it became a recommendation because it had a majority vote although the majority of the Committee actually abstained from voting on it. —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. The honourable senator is doing it again. The motion before the Chair has nothing to do with R-rated videos at all. SPEECH.PARA: Having regard to criterion (a), I think that the matter raised-
that is to say, the matter raised by Senator Walters-

It is very serious indeed. I and a number of others have spent four years sifting through, evaluating and considering evidence.
