TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate now has before it the report of the Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests, the so-called Helsham inquiry. It is a massive document of some 600 pages, and, as the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) said in his statement earlier today, it is available only in limited quantities and so it has not been possible for all honourable senators who are interested in this report to have the opportunity to peruse and study it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Lemonthyme and Southern Forests (Commission of Inquiry) Bill was granted royal assent on 30 April 1987 and came into operation on 8 May 1987. The Commission of Inquiry had 12 months in which to undertake a very difficult and complex task, namely, to report on certain matters related to the values and status of the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests areas of South West Tasmania. The commissioners appointed to undertake this task were the Honourable Michael Helsham, former Chief Judge in Equity of the Supreme Court of New South Wales, Mr Peter Hitchcock, manager of the Policy and Planning Division of the National Parks and Wildlife Service of New South Wales, and Mr Robert Wallace, Reader in Economics at the Flinders University of South Australia. The object of the Act is stated in section 4 in the following terms:
The object of this Act is to provide for measures that will enable effect to be given, in relation to the Lemonthyme area and Southern forests area, to Australia's obligations under the Convention-
that is, the World Heritage Convention-
in particular, the obligations to:
(a) identify and delineate the natural heritage and cultural heritage; and
(b) take appropriate measures to protect and conserve that heritage.

The Commission of Inquiry was in fact asked to report, in essence, on the relationship between the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests areas of Tasmania and their impact upon the already World Heritage listed area of South West Tasmania. The real purpose of the legislation, however, was to give the Commonwealth Government the opportunity to extend protection as it sees it for World Heritage areas into areas adjacent to or relating to an area already proclaimed and placed on the World Heritage List, and to extend Commonwealth control in an area which otherwise would not have come under Commonwealth control as a result of World Heritage listing a proposed listing.
In his second reading speech, the Minister at the time, Mr Cohen, indicated quite clearly that the Helsham inquiry was designed to bring some finality to this matter. The Minister said:
The issues are complex, but there is a need to settle the debate once and for all.

The challenge that the Government now faces is whether, having been given the report of the Commission of Inquiry, it is prepared to settle this debate once and for all, in line with the recommendations which have been made to it by the Commission of Inquiry, or was the Government's purpose all along to get a commission of inquiry to give it a series of recommendations which would allow it to extend its influence in relation to the preservation of South West Tasmania in accordance with its own political agenda? That is the matter that now squarely faces the chamber in looking at this report.

We know that there are time constraints that the Government must now observe. The explanatory memorandum produced in relation to the legislation indicates quite clearly that several clauses of the Bill provided for certain interim protection to be given to the areas nominated but that that interim protection regime would expire after a set period of time, namely, 42 days after the end of the 12-month inquiry period-if in fact not earlier.

The Helsham Commission was initially required to undertake an interim assessment of certain specified areas of the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests and to report on them as a matter of urgency. The Commission produced its interim report, dated 20 November 1987, in which it examined a number of particular areas and it pronounced four of them, constituting an area of 226 hectares out of a total area under review by the Commission of 283,300 hectares, as being areas which definitely did not qualify for protection under the regime which the Government had established.

At page 4 of the interim report of the Commission, the Commission is at very considerable pains to draw precise distinctions about what does and does not qualify for protection or what does or does not obtain the status of being something which is in need of special action on the part of the Commonwealth Government. Throughout, the Commission of Inquiry has been bound by the words of the legislation-the Government's legislation, to which those members on this side of the chamber objected in the first place. Nevertheless, the Commission has played this game by the rules given to it by the Government. I put it to the Senate that it is now incumbent on the Government, having established the rules of the game, having appointed the umpire, having financed the inquiry and having received the report, to act on the basis of the report and the recommendations it has been given.

Throughout the whole of this inquiry procedure the Federal Government was backwards and forwards to the courts. On the first occasion the matter went before the Chief Justice, Sir Anthony Mason, who in September 1987 issued certain injunctions to provide interim protection for part of the area. The Chief Justice in his reasons for judgment in the case Richardson v. the Forestry Commission and Another made it quite clear that scientific evidence had been put to him, as indeed it would later be put to the Commission of Inquiry, and on that basis he said-and I quote from page 27 of his judgment:

It is enough for me to say that on the evidence I conclude that there is a real, as distinct from a bare, possibility that the last mentioned areas form part of, or contribute to the integrity or values of, a world heritage area and that it is equally possible that the planned activities may adversely affect the integrity or values of a world heritage area.

His Honour was acting on the basis of scientific evidence which persuaded him to grant certain interim injunctions. Following the Chief Justice's judgment, on 3 September 1987 the Minister, Senator Richardson, issued a Press release, in which he said:
The open and impartial inquiry underway should be seen by all parties as a mechanism leading to properly informed Government decisions at both State and Commonwealth level.

In other words, the Minister indicated very clearly that this was an open inquiry, that it was under way, and that it should be seen by all parties, presumably including himself, as a mechanism leading to properly informed government decisions at both State and Commonwealth level. So the Minister repeated the underlying rationale for this inquiry: it would produce the evidence upon which the Government could make an informed and rational decision.

Nevertheless, the original legislation was again challenged in the Full High Court. It produced a judgment-dated 10 March 1988-in which the majority held that the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests (Commission of Inquiry) Act was valid-despite the comments, to which I have referred on a previous occasion, by His Honour Mr Justice Deane, who indicated the extent to which the Commonwealth was quite clearly engaged in an exercise in which it was seeking to minimise the impact of its own actions on the lives of the people in South West Tasmania. Indeed, His Honour Mr Justice Deane said:

. . . it seemed that the Commonwealth had not ascertained what the practical impact of the imposition of the restrictive regime would be on the lives and livelihood of those who own or use land within the protected areas for other than logging purposes.

Again, that will become central to the indications given by the Commission, because the Commission has in fact looked at those matters, and its conclusions are based very much on ascertaining what are the practical impacts on the lives of people in the area and recommending accordingly.

As I have said, I believe that the Commission of Inquiry was supplied with a great deal of very valuable and important information, and I shall draw attention to a couple of the submissions. In a submission entitled `Determining the role and management of environmentally significant forests', Dr Florence of the Department of Forestry at the Australian National University urged on the Commission a particular course of action. At page 28 of his submission he states:

We urge the commission of inquiry to recognise the enormous potential of forestry in Tasmania and to emphasise to the Commonwealth and State Governments that this potential can be realised in a socially acceptable way through appropriate resource planning. We believe it would be a very great pity indeed for the Commonwealth Government to jeopardise that potential by responding to strong environmental pressures of an immediate nature. The inquiry can do a great service to Tasmania and Australia through recommendations to government, which, while avoiding pre-emptory land use decisions, would seek to establish the planning structure needed to create a vigorous and stable industry for the future.
I put it to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that in fact that is precisely the obligation that the Commission has discharged in the 600-page report now before us.

It is not that the Commission was short of submissions from the other side of the debate, as it were. A final submission of about 200 pages made in November 1987 by the Combined Environment Group clearly urges on the Commission that it should take the whole of the area of the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests and grant it some status akin to World Heritage listing and prevent virtually anything being done in the area. In February 1988, the Combined Environment Group produced a document of about 400 pages entitled `The impact of resource withdrawal-revised final submission'. That submission, made to the Helsham Commission, detailed a considerable amount of information. It concluded that it had no hesitation in advocating to the Commission:
That no detriment to the forest industry would ensue from the nomination and listing of western Tasmania stage 2 as world heritage.

Other policy positions were available from the Institute of Foresters of Australia, and the Institute's national forest policy was put before the Commission. Also made available to the Commission was the Australian Conservation Foundation's report and the submission of the Tasmanian timber industry, as well as a multitude of other material. Nevertheless, it appeared during the Commission's inquiry that it would not come up with the recommendations that some of the Combined Environment Group people thought it ought to.

As a result, a couple of weeks ago, as the Commission's inquiry drew towards a conclusion, a campaign was undertaken in fact to poison the water and imply in advance that the Commission's report should be rejected. An article in the Australian, headed `Conservation groups to change tack in Tas forest fight', states:
Conservation groups in Tasmania are gearing up for a renewed campaign to save forests from logging because they seem certain they have lost the fight in the Hawke Government's Helsham inquiry.

The Sydney Morning Herald of 7 May 1988 contained an article headed `Why wilderness lovers are set for a new battle'. We have seen the continued attack on the Helsham inquiry prior to the presentation of its report by people who did not think that they would get out of it the result that they wanted. The Australian Conservation Foundation's document entitled `Helsham inquiry Tasmanian forests' begins by attacking the Helsham inquiry, as follows:
The Helsham inquiry failed to appreciate the importance of the integrity of an area to its World Heritage values.
The document states later:
The Helsham inquiry approached its task inappropriately on many accounts. Its findings may well not provide the Government with any clear lead.

They do provide the Government with a clear lead. What is objected to is that the clear lead is in the wrong direction as far as some of these groups are concerned. The Australian Conservation Foundation newsletter, for instance, tries to draw on the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) General Assembly in Costa Rica for support. If, in fact, it looked at the Costa Rica documents it would see that at its meeting on 1 to 10 February 1988 the IUCN in Costa Rica adopted a Tropical Forestry Action Plan in which it said in part:

Recognising that, after adequate provision has been made for the establishment of protected areas, other areas of tropical forest, specially selected for the purpose, may justifiably be allocated for the sustainable production of timber and other high value products.
In other words, that is attempting to draw a veil around the whole matter and assert that, from even international levels, protection is the only way to manage forestry resources.

The attack on the Helsham inquiry will proceed largely on the basis that the scientist on the Commission was in the minority and that the judge who headed the Commission and the economist who assisted him should be disregarded. It is interesting to note that that was never said by the proponents of environmental control when His Honour Mr Justice Fox produced his report on Ranger, when His Honour Mr Justice Hope produced his report on the national estate or when the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania, not headed by scientists or environmentalists, reported in 1982 why? It is because the recommendations of those inquiries were in fact in line with the preconceived agenda of some proponents. As a result, what we now have is this attack launched on the integrity, in a scientific sense, of the whole Helsham process and inquiry.

Turning to the Helsham report itself, I wish to indicate the way in which the Commission went about producing the report and summarising it. In its introductory comments, the Commission indicates that in large part it had been hoped that a memorandum of understanding entered into between the Commonwealth and Tasmania would have rendered a great deal of the inquiry unnecessary. The report says that this hope did not come to pass, I would say simply because the Commonwealth dishonoured the memorandum of understanding that it had with the Tasmanian Government, in exactly the same was as the Commonwealth dishonoured the 1984 Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM) agreement about the way in which it would go about consulting the States on World Heritage matters.

It is true, as the report indicates, that the Commission is not unanimous in its findings. That is perhaps one of the causes that have allowed people to attack the report although, as I shall seek to point out, I do not believe that that is a valid comment because not all of the recommendations are constituted of the same majority. In fact, the majority varies in relation to a number of recommendations put before us. The Commission clearly drew attention to two difficulties. The first, to be found on page 21 of the report, goes to the question that had originally been raised by His Honour Mr Justice Wilson in Richardson v. the Forestry Commission and Another when he said that the difficulty faced by the court and subsequently faced by the Commission was that some of the terminology, particularly the terminology `contribute to the integrity or values of a world heritage area', is not something that appears as a meaningful concept in any of the scientific documents or any of the conventions.

Secondly, at page 23, the report draws attention to the duty of the Commission to determine whether there are any `qualifying areas', as defined by the Act, in need of special protection and the difficulty faced in that regard because of the lack of clarity in both the Act and the World Heritage convention itself. I refer to the conclusions on page 421 of the third volume, as follows:
S. 8 (1) (a) requires the Commission to inquire into and report whether there are any qualifying areas in (or partly in) the inquiry area. It reports that there are five such areas.

The areas are located in the Forth Valley, at Cathedral Mountain within the Lemonthyme area, the north-east ridge of Mount Anne, in Mount Bobs-The Boomerang area, and at Exit Cave. They are all located in the Southern Forests. The report goes on to indicate that these areas will be dealt with in other chapters of the inquiry and in certain maps. I very much regret that the report says that they are delineated in maps 15, 17 and 18 because, in fact, they are delineated in maps 16, 17, 18 and 19. Part of the difficulty is that there are some inaccuracies in the text of the report, which makes it somewhat more difficult to follow the recommendations.

I turn now to the areas that have been specifically designated, and the first is the Forth Valley and Cradle Mountain area which is dealt with on page 177 of the second volume. It is there under the heading `Outstanding natural beauty' that the Commission has determined that two areas qualify for special protection because they are of outstanding natural beauty. At pages 181 and 182 the report indicates how the Commission assessed the Forth Valley and Cathedral Mountain area. If one looks at the second area which is regarded as a qualifying area, one can see that it relates to the Mount Bobs-The Boomerang area, which is assessed for protection because of its `special nature'. The special nature in that regard relates to the Commission's description on page 269, as follows:

The Commission has formed the view that the vegetation or botanical qualities of the Mt Bobs-The Boomerang area and the locality of the North-east Ridge of Mt Anne are of outstanding universal value from the scientific point of view.

There the emphasis is not on the natural beauty aspect but on the vegetation and botanical quality aspects. If one looks at the final area proposed, that is, Exit Cave, one finds that the Commission also had to draw its attention to what are called karst areas which relate to the cave system that has been formed. Karst is described as implying a landscape in which the dissolving of soluble rock leads to the development of underground drainage and land forms. Exit Cave is mentioned on page 213 in the second part of volume 1, in these terms:
The sum total of all the material is to leave the majority of Commissioners with the conviction that Exit Cave alone is a site, formation or area worthy of consideration as world heritage.
I think that area comprises about 19 kilometres of underground cave system.

It is interesting that on this occasion the majority is made up of two different commissioners from those who constituted the majority on the first four recommendations. So again there is some difficulty in coming to a clear picture of the majority view of the Committee, because it shifts. However, I draw attention to the fact that in relation to the earlier area-the Mount Bobs-The Boomerang and the Mount Anne area-the Commission accords recognition to the fact that the Forestry Commission of Tasmania is planning extensive reservation in that area and will give absolute protection to significant areas of alpine vegetation, rainforest, including King Billy Pine, and karst. In other words, in all of the Commission's undertakings, scientific evidence has been adduced and evaluated and the Commission has made a series of recommendations that there are within the whole of the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests five areas worthy of particular protection, and five areas only.

The question now is: What will the Government do in response, and why? I put it to the Senate that the Government is now on the horns of a dilemma which it has created. The Government established this commission of inquiry for a particular purpose; it gave it its guidelines and rules, supplied the resources, and selected the three commissioners. At the end of the day the commissioners have made a series of recommendations that the Government did not want to hear. The question will now be: What is the integrity of the Government in relation to the recommendations put before it? We know that at the moment the Government is anxious to establish some sort of new relationship with the forest industries. We also know that apart from the fact that certainly in the electorate of Eden-Monaro and elsewhere the Government is somewhat dependent upon the forest industries for campaign donations, as indeed Mr Young and Mr Loosley could testify, nevertheless, the Government is now divided in Caucus, given that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, Mr Snow, has indicated the extent to which he thinks that Senator Richardson is going overboard on this matter, and that the ALP is finding difficulty with, on the one hand, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, supported by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, and the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, who are seeking a more balanced approach to forestry management questions, and, on the other hand, Senator Richardson, who is attempting to maintain his born-again status through thick and thin. Finally buying into this argument is the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, who on 21 April 1988 announced what he called a `forests accord'.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Aulich, who smiles broadly and understands the way that these things are done, is an old practitioner in doing things in this fashion. It will be interesting to see whether the Tasmanian Labor senators are prepared to indicate any degree of support for the Tasmanian position and for the recommendations of the Helsham inquiry.

In conclusion, I point out that this inquiry was established by the Government for a particular purpose. All those who wished to make submissions were able to participate. It had the benefit of expert advice; it had the benefit of its own counsel, its own advisers, and its own integrity with a former Supreme Court judge as its Chairman in a position to make significant judgments as to competing claims and competing values. It has now reported. It has essentially reported in favour of the position put by the Tasmanian Government, the Tasmanian Forestry Commission and people seeking a balanced exploitation of the forest resources of South West Tasmania. He is no longer the shadow Minister for the environment. Apparently, he has now taken over the portfolios of industry, primary industry, mining, forests and, perhaps, finance. SPEECH.PARA: The Helsham Report of the Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests is a temporary victory for the shortsighted Tasmanian troglodytes and their multinational masters. The people and the forests will suffer. We have to go back and see why the Helsham inquiry was instituted in the first place. Several years ago the then Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Mr Cohen, came up with recommendations on some 21 areas of significance in Tasmania which were endangered by logging. He included such areas as Jackys Marsh, the Douglas-Apsley area, the Lemonthyme and the Southern Forests. Unfortunately, we have lost all those other areas as matters of concern and the Helsham inquiry was limited to only the Lemonthyme and the Southern Forests. That is sad because, of course, there are many other areas deserving of preservation. At any rate, the Helsham inquiry was instituted to discuss the relative merits of the World Heritage areas and look into the forestry matters. Well it did. Of course, the response by the logging industry was quite predictable. I quote from yesterday's Mercury newspaper dated Monday 16 May 1988. The headline on the front page reads: `The Helsham decision: Logging joy in forest findings'. The article states:
The Helsham Inquiry has confirmed the conservation movement's fears and delivered a stunning victory to the State Government and the forest industries.

This is from the Hobart Mercury which is owned by the same outfit which owns Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd (ANM) which, of course, is one of the largest end users of the forest products of Tasmania. We can take it that not only is the Mercury happy about this but the forestry industry is also. The article continues:
The long-awaited report of the inquiry-strongly opposed originally by the State Government-agrees that much of the disputed Lemonthyme and southern forests are not of World Heritage value.

It points out an interesting matter which I will go into in greater detail later. It says:

The Federal Government has the added problem of a dissenting report from the third member of the inquiry, Mr Peter Hitchcock, a forester and policy manager for the New South Wales National Parks Service. He has recommended that the entire forests be listed on the World Heritage Register.
He also has recommended World Heritage listing for one other area on the boundary of the southern forests protected area.

I will come back to that because I think it is important. Frankly, although Senator Puplick puts such store by the Helsham inquiry and says that the Government must now listen to its findings, the fact is that the Helsham inquiry is fatally flawed; it flawed itself. I do not know why Judge Helsham, who is a man of some experience, has allowed himself to be trapped by the selection of so-called experts. I do not know whether he or someone else selected these people. Who did he get? Who evaluated this mountain of evidence? Were they academics? Were they people who had shown some former ability to weigh the evidence and see both sides? No, these sorts of people were not chosen. I do not know whether he chose them but the people who were chosen were people such as John Quick. John Quick was engaged to review everyone else's evidence on tall eucalyptus with respect to World Heritage value. Up until two years previously he had been the Chief Commissioner of the Forestry Commission of Tasmania. The Forestry Commission of Tasmania has as its charter the support of the industry and over the years it has made no bones about this. It is there to back the industry; to support the industry and to make sure that the industry goes ahead. It is not the Department of the Environment. It is the State governmental arm of the forestry industry. Here we have the former Commissioner being commissioned by the Helsham inquiry to look at the evidence. How could he possibly come up with a balanced view when his overall drive in the preceding years had always been forestry and cutting down the trees? He is on public record, at a luncheon for FIAT which is a Tasmanian organisation for the forestry industry, as saying in November 1985:
We cannot afford to lock up a single hectare of forest.

This was one of the men brought in to evaluate the evidence. In a dispassionate way? Of course not; he was biased from the beginning. There was an outfit called ACIL Australia Pty Ltd, which is a consultancy firm which reviewed everyone else's evidence on the logging industry. For this purpose, it engaged Evan Shield, former Deputy Logging Manager of Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd until 1981. He was surely not a disinterested party. Another man who was employed was named David Trebeck, a former rural affairs adviser to the Liberal Party of Australia and an officer of the National Farmers Federation, which is spending hundreds and thousands of dollars opposing World Heritage listings in Australia. This man was hired to evaluate the evidence. How does one expect an unbiased judgment from such a man? The above three men were never put forward for public cross-examination and they were essentially allowed to have the last word behind the scenes.

There was a secret meeting of the Helsham inquiry people and the Forestry Commission Counsel in early December. This secret meeting was not revealed until the environmental movement found out about it and revealed it to the Press. It was a `Clayton's' inquiry and it did not use the power of subpoena. It was fatally flawed.

Let us look at the majority opinion first. Who are the people who gave the majority opinions? Michael Helsham, a judge and a retired air vice-marshal; Robert Wallace, a reader in economics at Flinders University. Economics is one of the dodgiest sciences I know of. If economics worked we would have full prosperity on earth today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Science?
—Senator Aulich questions whether it is a science. Economists are not well versed--
—It is like astrology. You throw up the bones and see how they land.

—It is like astrology in terms of interpreting bones and perhaps chicken entrails. But economists have no knowledge of the real world. They deal with this model of the earth which has infinite resources and can be manipulated within terms of supply and demand. The only person who had any knowledge of the real world-and he had great knowledge of the real world in forestry matters-was Peter Hitchcock, who was a forester and is the manager of policy and planning for the New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service. He was the dissenting voice. He was the person who actually knew what was going on and could see it. On page 423 of the report he gives his minority opinion in which he says:

SPEECH.PARA: Regrettably there are major differences between the majority view and the minority view in the reporting of qualifying areas. Those differences may be explicable in part at least by differences in:
the interpretation of the Act, in particular the interpretation of the definition of `qualifying areas';
the interpretation of the Convention;
the weighting placed on the criteria and the conditions of integrity and the Nomination Form; and
the approach adopted in translating heritage values into qualifying areas.
He goes on at some length. I will read a bit of it:
In essence the main points of my interpretation, which I believe to be legitimate, logical and appropriate to heritage values, are that:
lands which constitute a world heritage area for the purposes of the Act may be partly or even substantially within the existing world heritage area;

if a tract of land which constitutes a part of the cultural or natural heritage (a world heritage area) is partly located in the existing world heritage area, then that part which intrudes into the inquiry area remains a part of the cultural or natural heritage; i.e. a part of a world heritage area;

accordingly, in reporting such areas I report them as qualifying areas which are part of a world heritage area rather than report them as contributing areas. They may also be contributing areas, depending upon the interpretation of the Act;

Under his standards, he feels that almost all the area under the inquiry should be on the World Heritage List, which is in conflict with the majority report. The majority report rejects the World Heritage values of archaeological sites and wilderness. It rejects wilderness as a relevant criterion. It rejects World Heritage values of tall eucalypts. One of the most important elements of the natural heritage is the tall eucalypt forest ecosystem. The qualifying areas I have identified contain exceptional examples of the ecosystem which I consider to be of outstanding universal value from the point of view of science, conservation and natural beauty. They represent an exceptional opportunity to preserve, for the benefit of mankind outstanding examples of a unique forest ecosystem where natural processes of international interest still operate.

There are few if any other opportunities remaining in Australia for the conservation of comparable examples of tall eucalypt forest in pristine natural condition particularly in a wilderness setting where modern technological man has not yet had a significant impact on the ecosystem and its natural processes.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present a report entitled The National Crime Authority-An Initial Evaluation. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The occasion for this report is the lifting of the sunset clause in the National Crime Authority Act 1984, which would otherwise have terminated the life of the Authority on 30 June 1989. The Committee supports the lifting of the sunset clause although it considers that, because so many of the Authority's investigations and the resultant legal proceedings have yet to be completed, it can make only an initial evaluation of the Authority's performance at this time. Because legal proceedings are currently before the courts or are pending in relation to a number of matters the Committee has been obliged in its report to be circumspect and to confine itself to generalities.

Looking back on the debate leading up to the establishment of the National Crime Authority (NCA), the Committee considers that there was a clear expectation that the Authority would get results. The primary objective for which the Authority was established was, the Committee believes, to put significant criminals behind bars. In those terms the Authority is beginning to demonstrate success. It has put the Cornwell-Bull drug trafficking syndicate out of business and it has obtained convictions of significant figures under two of its other references. The terms of imprisonment imposed on Cornwell and Bull-23 years and 18 years respectively-indicate the gravity with which the courts viewed their activities. Terms of imprisonment of 24 years and 20 years have been imposed on principals under another reference, and the maximum term of imprisonment available for the offence concerned-three years-has been imposed on the principal under a third reference. Numerous other matters are before the courts at the moment.

The success of the Authority cannot merely be measured by the successful prosecutions resulting from its investigations, however. There was also an expectation that the establishment of the Authority would have a deterrent effect: that by its success in its investigations and, possibly, by its very existence, it would increase the fear of detection and apprehension in the minds of those who might be tempted to enter the field of organised criminal activity.

It is too early to say whether the Authority has succeeded in this second objective. The Committee therefore recommends that a more comprehensive evaluation of the Authority's work and of the success of the law enforcement strategy underpinning the establishment of the Authority be undertaken in three years time. By that stage more of the Authority's investigations and more of the resulting legal proceedings should have been completed and it should be possible to make some judgment as to whether the Authority has in fact altered the climate in which organised crime operates.

The Committee does not recommend any changes to the Bill lifting the sunset clause, the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, to which the House of Representatives has already agreed, nor does it recommend any changes to the legislation constituting the National Crime Authority at this stage. It has, however, identified the present limitations on the Authority's access to taxation records as a matter which it proposes to pursue in a further inquiry.

The Committee does, however, recommend some changes to the Authority's present handling of the police component of its staff. It became clear to the Committee in the course of this inquiry that there was considerable dissatisfaction in police ranks about their role in the Authority's investigations and the Authority's perceived attitude to police. The Committee recommends that the Authority give greater recognition to the expertise of experienced police officers and that they should be given a greater involvement in its investigations.

The Committee also recommends that the police component of the Authority's staff be given contracts rather than being seconded in order to overcome the problem of officers working together but being subject to different terms and conditions of employment, and it recommends that consideration be given to the appointment of a senior and respected serving or former police officer as a member of the Authority in order that police may be assured that their views are represented at the highest levels of the Authority. Finally, the Committee has recommended that the Authority give greater consideration to the use of police task forces external to the Authority as a means of carrying on its investigations.

While rejecting much of the criticism made of the secrecy surrounding the Authority's operations, the Committee has also recommended that the Authority give consideration to making greater use of its power to inform the public about the general conduct of its operations by holding public sittings and issuing public bulletins. Certain of the fears expressed at the time of the establishment of the Authority, both as to the obstacles which might lie in the way of its effective performance of its functions and the potential threat to civil liberties which it posed, appear to date to have proven groundless.

So far from being a `ninth police force', as some have claimed, the Authority is a unique and novel investigative agency, combining elements of traditional law enforcement agencies with the powers of a royal commission and able to use the one to complement the other. The Committee believes that Mr Justice Stewart, the members and senior staff of the Authority deserve credit for having turned this experiment into a successful working reality.

Having made those remarks about the work of the Committee, I wish to comment particularly about the actions of others in the community who are not so charitably minded about the activities of the National Crime Authority. One person in particular about whom I express grave concern is a prominent Melbourne lawyer by the name of Mr Frank Galbally. It is significant that in the Press he is never referred to as a well respected or even a highly successful lawyer: he is simply referred to as a prominent Melbourne lawyer.

Mr Galbally's firm has been recently acting for two persons accused of serious charges in New South Wales-Jennifer and Giuseppe Sergi. Mr Galbally has appeared for one of those persons. On the strength of conspiracy charges against his client being dismissed a matter of days ago, Mr Galbally has taken it upon himself to deliver a sweeping broadside against the National Crime Authority, describing it as a disastrous body. Never mind the fact that his client might still be proceeded against by way of ex officio indictment. Never mind that the magistrate's decision is capable of review on a matter of law. No, Mr Galbally could not wait to seize the opportunity to promote himself and his very expensive services. This performance is entirely consistent with his long history as a notorious media grandstander and ambulance chaser.

However, a matter of most utter concern is that, whilst the conspiracy charges against his client-a co-accused of Mr Al Grassby-were dismissed, Mr Grassby still faces a charge of criminal defamation. As Mr Galbally well knows, this matter has been adjourned to enable the magistrate to decide whether the defamation proceedings should be stayed on the grounds of inordinate delay in the bringing of the proceedings. That matter will be listed for mention tomorrow and, as I understand it, a judgment will be delivered next Friday.

Even more important is the fact that the question of costs is still pending. In typical style, Mr Galbally has engaged in a classic piece of hyperbole and overblown rhetoric, calling the case `the most disgraceful example of a prosecution I have seen in 40 years'. It does not take much imagination to recognise that these remarks could well be seen as a veiled attempt to influence the outcome of the outstanding proceedings. By publicly discrediting the NCA Mr Galbally improves his chance of success on the question of costs. As will be well understood, the question of a stay is one of discretion and the magistrate will take into account a number of factors-not simply the question of delay but also whether the Crown has acted properly, whether it has exercised due diligence, whether it comes before the court with clean hands and whether it is proper in all the circumstances that the matter should be allowed to proceed. In relation to each of those matters the magistrate must make a very careful and balanced judgment. Mr Galbally's remarks can only have the effect of making the magistrate's task much harder, and indeed they could improperly influence the outcome.

Mr Galbally's behaviour and his actions are calculated to undermine public confidence in the NCA. Mr Galbally is not concerned with the effect of enforcement of the criminal justice system in this country. If he had any serious concern about the operations of the NCA he should have made a submission to the parliamentary Joint Committee, the report of which I am now speaking to. In February 1988, following the introduction of the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 in the House of Representatives to lift the sunset clause, the Committee wrote again to the four State Premiers who at that time had not responded to our request for cooperation. It also wrote again to the State and Federal police associations and to the legal academics and criminologists whom it had previously contacted; and it extended an invitation for submissions from the Law Council of Australia, law societies and bar associations, the Council for Civil Liberties, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and certain judges, lawyers and an investigative journalist who had made substantial submissions to the original inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs into the National Crime Authority Bill 1983.

Finally, on 5 March 1988 the Committee placed advertisements in the national Press calling on interested persons and organisations to make submissions to its inquiry by 31 March. A total of 61 persons and bodies were contacted and 21 submissions were received. The Committee held two in camera hearings in Canberra in April 1988. However, Mr Galbally did not bother to make any submission whatsoever, either oral or written. Rather, he has chosen to seize an opportunity to make yet another grubby media appearance and mouth off in characteristically broad terms, which does nothing to contribute to the quality of debate about the role of the NCA, and he did not attempt to distinguish between the charges that are outstanding and those that have been dismissed. I think it can be properly said that Mr Galbally's actions should be the subject of very close scrutiny by the appropriate law enforcement officers to determine whether he is in contempt of the court. Certainly one would have thought that, if the NCA had come out after the decision to dismiss the charges and been critical of the decision, it would have been properly lambasted by the community at large and certainly by the legal profession in particular.

My purpose in speaking this afternoon is not to attempt in any way to influence the proper decisions that must be made impartially by judicial officers; instead, it is to draw attention to what I regard as a very serious deficiency in the conduct of one particular individual whose actions are calculated only to make the task of law enforcement so much harder in this country. A proper and reasoned evaluation of the NCA cannot be made in a definitive sense at this stage and it will be necessary to continue a monitoring process. I look forward to the Committee's exercising very close scrutiny and hearing directly from officers of the Authority. I think the NCA should take into account the very proper public concerns that have been expressed. If the alternative is simply to vacate the field and allow organised crime to conduct its activities without any form of supervisory body, I think that would be a disaster for law enforcement and justice in this country and it would be a very one-sided victory for the forces of darkness.

Mr Galbally's comments have made it that much harder for a body such as the NCA to carry out its proper responsibilities. Temperate criticism is one thing but thoroughly intemperate and tendentious comments of the nature made by Mr Galbally are entirely another. I regard it as utterly inappropriate and inexcusable for him to deliver this tirade. I hope that in the future any similar performance is treated with the contempt that it deserves. I welcome the report and look forward to participating further in the activities of the Committee and in being scrupulous in ensuring that the NCA remains an efficient and effective body in the fight against all levels of crime in this country. Without a strong crime fighting body there can be no effective guarantee of safety for the public at large. I think that we all have a very strong self-interest to ensure that law enforcement agencies are given all the support they need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to speak briefly to the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority report; it has been presented at an opportune time because public debate on the National Crime Authority (NCA) is heating up. Very powerful vested interests in this country want to see the NCA discredited. I do not wish to see it discredited because I still believe that the combination of professional expertise, the national and international perspective of the NCA and its special powers make it the only way to curb major organised crime in this country. In my opinion it is the only way to counter the level of sophistication, the financial resources and professional expertise available to major criminals.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we have found that traditional police forces will continually run up against brick walls in these areas, brick walls of State boundaries, restricted jurisdictions, conflicting priorities, lack of resources, lack of staff, including legal, accounting and financial skills, and a community reluctant to extend electronic listening powers or coercive powers in the gathering of evidence. In many of those areas one can understand the community's reluctance.

We have given the NCA a major responsibility and we have given it exceptional powers to meet that responsibility. In my opinion it has provided the first major obstacle to the `Mr Bigs' of Australian crime. It is a hindrance to their organisations and the enormous power, influence and wealth that they command. As stated in the report, few of these persons have yet been put behind bars, but there is little doubt on the evidence put before the Committee that they are concerned-and perhaps concerned for the first time. They want to see the NCA discredited. If the NCA is forced onto the defensive, and if public support wanes, it will soon be undermined and it will soon become ineffective.

There is a lot working against the NCA. There is a level of corruption at senior levels in some existing police forces that can be described only as shocking, and when that is linked with political corruption it becomes terrifying. One need only reflect briefly on what is coming out of the Fitzgerald inquiry in Queensland. I applaud the fact that Mr Greiner is to institute a similar investigation in New South Wales. I guess it was brought home to me when the Committee was taking evidence in another inquiry and heard from a witness who had received a death threat because of his knowledge of certain criminal activity. Because of this knowledge he put to us his dilemma as to who he should turn to if he cannot turn for protection to the police or to those who are elected to office. One sees the difficulties facing the NCA in carrying out its task when one reflects on the fact that of two police officers assigned to it as liaison officers by State police forces, one is currently on criminal charges and the other has personally acknowledged that he is corrupt. When assessing the record of the NCA to date, one must take such difficulties into account.

Regrettably, my State of South Australia is not exempt from what we are seeing elsewhere in Australia. There is growing evidence of police corruption in South Australia-of police corruption facilitating organised crime in areas of drugs, prostitution and SP bookmaking to an extent which most South Australians would have thought unbelievable. I regret to say that I see insufficient determination on the part of the South Australian Police Force to root out that evil from within. I also see insufficient acknowledgment by the South Australian Government of the problem and insufficient efforts by that Government to counter it. For the South Australian Government simply to say that a need for an inquiry would be brought to its attention by the NCA is to misunderstand the responsibility of the NCA. It is in fact the responsibility of the State Government. I am pleased that in an answer to a question in this chamber some time ago, at least Senator Tate was prepared to acknowledge that.

I do not wish to see Fitzgerald-type inquiries instituted unnecessarily, obviously on civil libertarian grounds. But I regret that in South Australia there is building public evidence that is coming very close at this stage to warranting such an inquiry. I remind the Senate that it is the honest police officers-the majority of police officers-who deserve our protection. As we know, they are critical to securing the type of lifestyle that we wish and expect in this country. As has been seen in Queensland, a public inquiry may, in some circumstances, be the only way to counter the insidious pressures that are put upon them by those to whom they traditionally turn for an example-their leaders within the police force. I think we, in this chamber, must accept that these police are, to a considerable extent, in my opinion anyway, underpaid and their services underrecognised. It is up to the Government and this Parliament to do something to remedy such shortcomings.

Apart from the obstacle of corruption, the NCA will also be under pressure from those who have normal professional jealousies-that is, within existing police forces-and from those who argue that the NCA be an entirely different type of body from that which it now is, those who argue that its functions be simply intelligence gathering rather than investigative. So the pressures on the NCA are great. This indicates to me that there is an even greater responsibility on those of us who see that it has to play a critical role in countering organised crime in the future to ensure that it is fairly and properly defended. Of course, that cannot be done without the proper evaluation of how the NCA is going about its task. That is a responsibility that falls on the Government. It falls on the Minister for Justice in this chamber. It falls on other Ministers and attorneys-general and justice Ministers within the States. They must not seek to avoid their responsibilities. In passing, I say that I regret that Senator Tate, for example, today indicated that, in the case of the prosecution of the South Australian Assistant Commissioner Harvey, he had not called for an inquiry and, therefore, was not in possession of the facts which I would like to see him possess. It is not only the responsibility of the Government to ensure that this body is carrying out its functions in a proper way but it is also the responsibility of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority which has put down this report today. This Committee has a responsibility of assuring the public that the NCA deserves the respect that we believe is necessary for it to carry out its functions properly and efficiently.

There have been a number of serious criticisms of the NCA-some of them very recently. Two of these I reflected upon a couple of months ago in this chamber and I mentioned one of them a moment ago. The first was the dismissal by a magistrate of a case of conspiracy against a South Australian senior police officer, Assistant Commissioner Harvey, who is currently suspended. This case of conspiracy between him and others was dismissed by the magistrate on the basis that there was insufficient evidence to put the case before a jury. One wonders how the proceedings got to that stage if there was simply insufficient evidence to put before the magistrate. The second case was also South Australian. It was one of conspiracy against police officers-unnamed in South Australia because of a suppression order and I will not name them now-which was also dismissed at the magistrate's level and incurred certain public criticism of the NCA. The third case, only a few days ago, was the dismissal of the case against Mr Al Grassby and others. It was not the dismissal that was of significance but the very critical comments made of the NCA by the magistrate.

The Joint Committee is able, and has a responsibility, to investigate these matters. In this report, we have spoken of the NCA's performance generally but the Committee also has a responsibility to investigate these matters specifically and ensure that the NCA is meeting its charter responsibilities. In the first two instances, the Committee has been able to question members of the National Crime Authority at some length in relation to these matters. The action against unnamed police officers in South Australia turned out to be a request from the South Australian Police Commissioner that the NCA carry out an investigation for the South Australian authorities. The South Australian authorities then decided to take action. Therefore, it logically followed that when the case failed, it was unfair of the Press to be critical of the NCA in its operation. It simply was not an NCA prosecution. We were able to establish that at the committee level and I am pleased to stand here and assure the Parliament of that fact and, therefore, hopefully in some small way to reassure the public on that matter.

The second criticism of South Australia is not so easily dismissed. Although I regret that I cannot go into details, it is fair to say that the NCA recognises some shortcomings in its handling of that matter, and in making its explanation to the Committee it raised aspects of that particular prosecution which will require further investigation by the Committee before I and others can stand in this place and reassure the public. Certainly, I will be looking to the Committee to continue its investigation of that matter in order that we can give the Parliament those reassurances.

The third matter-the Al Grassby prosecution-falls into a similar category. Very serious allegations have been made about the prosecution in that instance and of the NCA in particular. I can assure you, Mr Deputy President, that the Committee will, in that instance, investigate the matter thoroughly and report to this Parliament. It will take what remedial action it thinks necessary in order that the public can maintain the confidence that is necessary for the NCA to function effectively.

I simply wanted to make those few comments to reassure you, Mr Deputy President, and the Senate that the Committee has an important responsibility to deal with these criticisms specifically and not just to deal with the matters in the general way that has appeared in this preliminary report put down today. Mr Deputy President, you can expect the Committee to come back on these matters in due course.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
