DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I table a report entitled One Vote, One Value, being the report of the Committee's inquiry into the Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill 1987, together with a supplementary paper to the report. I seek leave to move a motion relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

One Vote, One Value is the title of the first report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. The report presents the findings of the Committee's inquiry into the Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill 1987. The Bill seeks to enshrine in the Constitution the principle of one vote one value by requiring that the numbers of voters in electorates are, as nearly as practicable, the same. The Bill aims to rid voters of the problem of malapportionment; that is, the practice of unequally apportioning voters between electorates. The Committee makes a clear distinction between malapportionment and gerrymandering. Honourable senators may be interested to know that the term `gerrymander' came originally from Governor Elbridge Gerry of Massachusetts in the early part of the last century and refers to boundary rigging. It does not refer to numbers. The malapportionment refers to the numbers in an electorate and the unequal apportionment of those numbers from electorate to electorate. The Committee notes in its report that the achievement of one vote one value does not stop the possibility of gerrymandering.

The Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill 1987 was introduced into the Senate by the Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Michael Macklin, on 23 September 1987. The Senate referred the Bill to the Committee for inquiry and report on 28 October 1987. In inquiring into Senator Macklin's Bill, the Committee continued the work of its predecessor, the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. Prior to the dissolution of the Thirty-fourth Parliament, the Joint Select Committee was inquiring into the Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill 1985. The 1985 Bill was an earlier version of the 1987 Bill. The Committee notes in its report that both Senator Macklin's 1985 Bill and the 1987 Bill are very similar to the Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill 1974 which was introduced into the Parliament by a former Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam. The Committee has found that there is a clear historical trend in Australia towards fairer electoral boundaries which seek to give all electors an equal say in determining who shall form their government. Nevertheless, it believes that there is a pressing need for further reforms in State electoral laws as they apply to the Western Australian Legislative Council, the Western Australian Legislative Assembly, the Tasmanian Legislative Council and the Queensland Legislative Assembly.

Using the three accepted measures of malapportionment-the David-Eisenberg index, the Dauer-Kelsay index and the Gini index-the gross malapportionment evident in each of the chambers cited cries out for action. It is unfair and undemocratic for an Assembly seat in Queensland to have only 8,256 voters while another has more than 25,000 voters. It is unfair and undemocratic for one electorate in the Western Australian Legislative Council to have about 12,000 electors per member while another has 40,000 electors per member. In this regard it is difficult to understand the stand taken by Opposition members of the Committee who, in a dissenting report, oppose the concept of one vote one value. Given the bipartisan support for equality of electorates in the House of Representatives, I cannot understand how they oppose equal State electorates.

The arguments are twofold. The first is that the Senate is malapportioned and, therefore, the States should be left to sort out their own malapportionment and to escape the test of fairness. However, in making that statement, they forget that the Senate was an historical compromise. If they want to go a bit further-I and many honourable senators here would not oppose it-they could attempt to reform what I believe is an undemocratic House. However, I do not think that they are going that far. As an historical compromise, the Senate is a States House. That is why it was established in that way. More importantly, the Government is not formed in the Senate. In some of the malapportioned Houses to which I have referred, the opposite is the case. The second aspect of the argument goes to States' rights. Whereas some States have shown no inclination to reform, the trend over time towards reform has been patchy and some States-particularly those that I have mentioned-have shown absolutely no interest in reform.

The Committee has found that most Australian parliaments now provide that electoral boundaries should be drawn so that electorates have enrolments which vary from the State average by less than 10 per cent. In the Northern Territory, the maximum is 20 per cent. The Committee concludes that, as a general principle, redistributions should aim to have electoral enrolments which are within 10 per cent of the average enrolment. Regrettably, the Committee is unable to accept the Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill 1987, as it was referred to the Committee, as a model for implementing one vote one value. In particular, the Committee has been unable to accept the equality tests which are contained in the Bill. The Committee has some concerns with the Bill's provisions for elections at large. It has also found the Bill to be deficient in its lack of a provision for the filling of casual vacancies.

The Committee believes that amendments to the 1987 Bill proposed by Senator Macklin and designed to prevent the practice of gerrymandering are lacking in certainty and, therefore, are impractical. The Committee notes in its report that electoral reforms with regard to one vote one value have already occurred in South Australia and Victoria and that in Western Australia there has been an attempt at reform. The Committee concludes that reform may occur in individual States, but that there is no guarantee of this. The Committee has concluded that the Federal Government has a clear responsibility to act to overcome what the Committee sees as an infringement of the individual rights of Australians to have an equal say in choosing their governments. The Committee's view is that the final question in achieving one vote one value is one of State governments' rights versus individuals' rights and that the latter is of paramount importance. The Committee recommends strongly that the views of Australian voters on one vote one value be tested by way of a referendum.

The tabling of this report represents the culmination of work which began with the former Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform in 1985 which was chaired by Senator Robert Ray. The Committee wishes to express its gratitude to the Joint Select Committee for its work and, in particular, for the excellent chairmanship of Senator Ray. The Joint Select Committee held public hearings in Brisbane and Perth and received a substantial amount of evidence which has been most useful to the Electoral Matters Committee. The Committee has also been greatly assisted in its inquiry by the Attorney-General's Department and the Australian Electoral Commission and, in particular, the Electoral Commissioner, Dr Colin Hughes. On behalf of the Committee I also thank the staff of the former Joint Select Committee, Don Nairn and, later on for a short period, Mike Fetter. I thank also the Committee's current small secretariat, Trevor Rowe and Helen Misa, for the willing support given to the inquiry and their capacity for extremely hard work in the last few weeks.

Since completing the drafting of its report the Committee has received new data on electoral divisions, in particular in Western Australia, which has recently undergone a redistribution as a result of very limited electoral reform proposals passed by both Houses of Parliament in that State last year. The Committee has prepared, therefore, a supplementary paper to its report which includes this new data. The data shows that while the situation in Western Australia has improved marginally, when measured by any of the indices to which I have already referred and used by the Committee, the malapportionment in Western Australia still shows the worst distortions of any State. In other words, the same arguments still apply despite the reported changes contained in the supplementary papers attached to the report. I commend the report to honourable senators and trust that it will contribute to healthy and constructive debate on the question of electoral reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters which has just tabled its report-One Vote, One Value. I therefore rise to comment briefly on the report with quite a deal of pride in its outcome. I think that when honourable senators and the wider community have had a chance to read the report it will be found to be a document of very considerable educational and other benefit to the community and, indeed, to the Parliament because it contains a great deal of very interesting, important and worthwhile information on the whole subject of gerrymanders and malapportionments in electoral practices and the like. I would venture to say that this report is a report which, in terms of its factual content, will be very valued by many people and institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that I would also like to join with Senator Beahan, who tabled the report on behalf of the Committee, in thanking the staff of the Committee, in particular our secretary, Trevor Rowe, and our assistant, Helen Misa, for the enormous amount of work they have done. I hope that they feel, as they should, that they can take great credit from the contribution they have made.

I feel that some of the remarks that have been made both by Senator Beahan here and by Mr Lee in the other House in tabling this report may lead to some misunderstanding on the part of listeners and of readers of Hansard as to what was agreed and not agreed in the report. I would like to direct my comments to that area because I should say at the outset that there is a significant minority report in the tabled document so far as the key recommendation of the Committee is concerned. I refer to the recommendation that we should put to the test, in the form of a referendum, the issue of one vote one value, so-called. I will come back to that in a moment because I think that is one of the most misleading statements that has been made in a long time in this Parliament and outside.

However, leaving that aside for the moment, there is some misunderstanding as to the nature of the dissenting view that has been expressed in the report. I point out also that it is a dissenting view of a minority which comprises only marginally less than half of the Committee members. In regard to the key recommendation, the Committee was divided 6:4. The six members of the Committee who represented the majority comprised the five Labor members plus, understandably, of course, the Australian Democrat representative. On the other side were the three Committee members from the two major coalition parties-the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia-plus Senator Harradine. They formed a minority of four to the majority of six. Therefore, there was a divided view by the Committee on the key premise.

Tonight I want to devote a little time to this because what we are really talking about in the Committee report is, in my view, the two important referendum issues of the four issues that will be put to the Australian people in early September. This is assuming the four referendum Bills pass through the Parliament-which I understand will be the case because the Australian Democrats will support the Government in the Senate in passing these. Of course, one of those four Bills is a Bill to put to referendum:
An Act to alter the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia.
It has been said elsewhere by the Hon. Ralph Hunt and others that that in itself is a very misleading title for any referendum Bill. It is grossly misleading.

TALK.START.PARA: —The choice of such a title casts a reflection on the Government in putting it forward.

—As Senator Stone said, it does cast a great deal of doubt on the good faith of the Government in putting it forward. It also highlights the fact that, of course, the proposals were put forward before the Constitutional Commission, which had been set up by the Government at great cost, had even reported. The whole of the referendum legislation is a hoax. The referendum Bill to which this report relates is at least equal to the greatest of the hoaxes.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just get the matter in perspective because there have been a lot of misleading statements in recent days by the Government, the media and others, including, I would have to say, Senator Beahan and in the other place, Mr Lee, as to the basis for the Opposition's opposition to the referendum proposal. The implication of what Senator Beahan said and what Mr Lee said in the other place was that somehow or other the Liberal and National Party coalition was opposed to the principle of one vote one value. That has never been at issue in this debate. It was not at issue in the consideration of this report. There is no senator on this side of the House who would not agree that a more equal numbering of voters in electorates is a desirable thing at both State and Federal level. We have supported it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the National Party agree with that?

—Yes; we have supported it and pursued it at Federal level. The Government is ignoring the fact that other considerations are involved in election procedures and practices, particularly when those procedures and practices relate to the States. Anyone listening to Government spokesmen on this matter would think there was no such thing in this country as a federation. This whole nation has been built as a federation. It was built on a compact between a Federal Government and State governments, and an essential element of that compact was that the States would give to the Commonwealth certain powers and keep to themselves, by agreement, all the others.

SPEECH.PARA: An essential right of the States is the right to determine their electoral practices and their electoral systems. The great myth, the great hoax, being put around in recent days is that somehow or other the rights of the States do not matter. That is something with which we on this side of the chamber fundamentally disagree. That is the fundamental disagreement in this debate. State elections are, under our Constitution, the prerogative of the States.

Another point has been ignored in this debate on the tabling of this report. We have to point out very clearly that over recent years there has been a significant move in the States towards more equal numbering in terms of the balance between electorates. Four of the six States have moved significantly over recent years to a more equal distribution of voters in the electorates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will Queensland ever move of its own volition?

—I think it will because the trend has been followed progressively over recent years. Let me quote from the preface to the report, signed by the Chairman of the Committee, Mr Lee, which says, and it is repeated elsewhere in the report:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has found there to be a clear historical trend in Australia towards fairer electoral boundaries which seek to give all electors an equal say in determining who shall form their government.
In the dissenting or minority report-it is only just a minority report; four to six-to which I was a party--

TALK.START.PARA: —Six always beats four-except in Queensland.

—One very sad thing about democracy in this country-or the lack of it so far as the other side of politics is concerned-is that members of the Australian Labor Party play politics entirely on the basis of numbers. There are more things to politics than that. The electors of Australia are waking up to that. One key point in the minority report, signed by the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, Mr Blunt, by Mr Shack, by myself and by Senator Harradine is referred to in paragraph 7, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee finds `there is a clear historical trend towards fairer electoral boundaries . . .' and concludes, in time individual States may achieve electoral reform.
That is the Committee's statement. The minority four say:

This recognition of the progress to reform undermines the justification for Commonwealth involvement to force change in an area where States are not only sovereign but also are taking action. It may also limit progress to further voluntary change.

That is an important point that needs to be made in this debate and in the wider consideration of this report by the Parliament and the community. The assumption is that by the Federal Government riding jack boot over the States somehow or other we will be able to provide, as Federal politicians in the Federal Parliament, a better and fairer system for the States. Setting aside altogether the rights of the States, to which I have already referred-rights that those on the opposite side of politics completely ignore-the assumption that Federal interference, involvement and coercion will lead to a fairer and better electoral system in the States is a very questionable proposition. The history of this country is replete with examples of coercion and compulsion leading to a result totally counterproductive to what the proponents of the changes might have had.
I also draw the Senate's attention to some other important points made in the dissenting report. Let me quote two or three of them. The first is that we on this side of politics believe it is:

. . . inappropriate for any constitutional referenda to proceed without it first being considered by a conference of elected representatives of the Commonwealth and the States, i.e. a Constitutional Convention.

That is of fundamental importance. In 1985 the Hawke Government said, `We think if we set up a group of 20 or thereabouts absolutely unelected representatives and get them to look at change to the Constitution, and if we get our numbers right in terms of who those people are, we will get a result that will benefit the ideology that we in the Labor Party are putting forward and we will get a better system'. Over the last three years, and now without even waiting for the final report of the Constitutional Commission which the Government set up, the Government has prostituted the normal process for looking at constitutional change in this country which has been accepted on a bipartisan basis for many years in the form of a Constitutional Convention.

A further point is that the report suggests that we would have fair elections if we followed the proposals now enshrined in the Constitution referendum Bills. That ignores a fundamental point-a point Senator Beahan alluded to; even Government members would recognise this-that even if we went ahead with this proposal it would not lead to fair elections if by `fair elections' we mean exactly one vote one value, whatever that means. It is a nonsense term because it is so open to differing interpretation. The Committee found that the proposal in Senator Macklin's Bill had inherent defects, and none of the 10 members of the Committee-including Senator Coulter, the Australian Democrats' representative on the Committee-dissented from the finding of the Committee that the Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill 1987, which was the basis of the Committee's report, had inherent defects in it. One of the things that the Bill does not do, one of the things that the constitutional referendum proposals presently before the Parliament do not do, is tackle the question of gerrymanders. As we all know, there are two major elements of difficulty in terms of conducting elections-namely, malapportionment and gerrymanders. They are fundamentally different.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they go hand in hand.
—Senator Ray will acknowledge that they are fundamentally different.
—But you can have both at one time.

—I assume that Senator Ray would agree with me-surely he could not disagree-that neither this Bill nor the constitutional referendum proposal that the Government has put forward touches the area of gerrymanders.
—It severely limits the opportunity for them. It does not wipe them out.
—It does not deal specifically with gerrymanders.
—That is patently absurd.
—This is the first time that I have heard Senator Schacht say that this operation tackles or deals with gerrymanders. It does not and I challenge the honourable senator to say the opposite.
—I will. I will speak in a moment and explain it to you-slowly so that you can understand it.
—Order, Senator Schacht. You can make a speech later if you wish.

—I have already touched on the other main points in the dissenting report. However, they are worth quoting if for no other reason than to get them onto the record. Point 4 of the dissenting report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed referendum is in conflict with the philosphy of a `Federal Compact', which is a corner stone of the Federation as expressed in Sections 106 and 107 of the Constitution.
The intrusion of the Commonwealth is unwarranted and would be a first step in dissolving our federal system.

That does not seem to be a matter of great moment to members of the Government. Unless I misunderstood him, Senator Beahan said in his comments that one of the things he would not mind seeing at all is the abandonment of the Senate. But that, of course, is not surprising because for many years that has been the ultimate goal of the Australian Labor Party. That is the whole basis for the debate that is taking place now as to the reasons and the motivation for the constitutional referendum Bills that are now before the Parliament. There is no logical reason for bringing these Bills into the Parliament at this time other than to reduce, weaken and ultimately destroy the Senate. I defy members of the Government opposite to argue contrary to that.

A majority of the Committee also put forward a proposal to incorporate provisions affecting State electoral laws. This proposal is addressed by point 8-the final point-in the dissenting report. The dissenting report states:

The proposal to incorporate provisions affecting State electoral laws in the Commonwealth Constitution will inevitably result in the High Court becoming involved in disputes over these issues. These disputes are invariably Party political in character. This will politicise the Court. Additionally, there are some limits through Section 24 of the Constitution on the right of the Commonwealth to draw electoral boundaries.
We have not looked at testing the constitutionality of what is being talked about at the moment. Although that is another matter, it is one of very great significance and potential importance.

This is a very important report because of its value so far as its factual content is concerned. It is also a very valuable report in that it brings out very starkly and very clearly the issues involved in one of the basic matters that are going to be put to the Australian people in the next few months in terms of changing our Constitution. I hope that the report will be very widely read. It should form an integral part of the debate that will be taking place in the next few months.

I believe that the electorate and this Parliament will say two things of the majority report when they look at the content of the report and the issues involved. First, they will say the recommendations in the report will not inevitably lead to fairer elections. Let me repeat that there is no dispute between this side of the chamber and the Government in terms of the desirability of moving at the State level as we have at the Federal level-this has been done in at least four of the six States-towards a more equitable and more equal distribution of numbers in electorates.

The second point that will be debated and must be debated and given the greatest consideration is the relationship involved in a federal compact. Whether we like the fact that we have a federal system is a separate point. We have a federal compact between a Federal government and State governments and parliaments. I believe that the Australian community as a whole will look very seriously at and be very worried about a jack boots approach such as is proposed here which rides roughshod over the rights of the States.

I am very pleased to have been a member of the Committee. I want to commend everybody involved for the hard work that has been put into this very high quality report. I am also very pleased to have been one of the four members of the Committee who signed the dissenting report. I believe that accepting the majority report of this Committee would place our Federal system in jeopardy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters into the Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill 1987, which I first introduced over four years ago-in fact, on 2 April 1984. That Bill has been through quite a number of stages. Interestingly enough, Senator Short managed to miss one of those stages, as did other people who were involved in the minority report. One of the fundamentally important points that the members of the Committee involved with the dissenting report wished to make was contained in the following statement:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe it inappropriate for any constitutional referenda to proceed without it first being considered by a conference of elected representatives of the Commonwealth and the States, i.e. a Constitutional Convention.

Actually, on 1 August 1985 a vote was taken on this Bill at the Constitutional Convention. The vote was 39 to 29. I draw Senator Short's attention to the fact that the first fundamental point of the dissenting report was achieved. Obviously, he had not bothered to do his homework and did not know that my private member's Bill had been on the agenda in Brisbane, had been considered and had been passed. It was the only private member's Bill on the agenda and, therefore, it was the only one that had a chance of being passed, and it was passed.

I do not want to go into enormous detail with regard to some of the propositions that the Committee has come up with. Fairly obviously, I would still disagree with a number of them. For example, I would still disagree with the recommendation on the way that one may draft a constitutional Bill as distinct from another piece of legislation. Hence, I would feel that `something as near as practicable' is a constitutional wording whereas `10 per cent', which was in my later Bill, is more legislative wording. However, I think the important point is that the majority of the Committee found in favour of the principle of putting this issue to the people.

I find it very difficult to understand Senator Short's position when he says that the proposed referendum is in conflict with the philosophy of a federal compact. In fact, the federal compact, if Senator Short wishes to read it, has a section in which the people are actually asked about their own Constitution. Section 128 provides for a method whereby we can go to the people and ask, `Do you wish to change the Constitution in that regard?'. That seems to me to be perfectly in keeping with the federal compact. For the life of me, I cannot see how a proposed referendum can be in conflict with that if it is conducted correctly under section 128. Whether the people accept it is a different matter, but asking the people certainly cannot be in conflict with the federal compact. To suggest that, I think, is absurd and demonstrates an obviously myopic reading of the Constitution.

I wish to look in some detail at a point which the Opposition has raised on a number of occasions and which Senator Short has raised here tonight. It is to do with the difference between malapportionment and gerrymander. As I understand the Opposition's position, it is something like this: `We will be opposing the Bill anyhow, but one of the reasons we do not think the Bill is any good is that it does not reform the entire world'. It seems to me that when those two reasons are distilled that they are in conflict. I had always believed that the Liberal Party was a reformist party, believing that if one could reform part of the world one might give it a shot, but obviously it is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may have been Alfred Deakin.

—It may very well have been Alfred Deakin. It seems to me that if one attempts to do away with one part of the rorting of the system, that is worth while supporting. I noticed that Senator Short and those who supported him in the minority report skirted very carefully around any proposal or any suggested amendment dealing with the gerrymander. There is one good reason for that, of course. That is, as anybody who bothers to read the judgments of the United States Supreme Court on this matter will know, that the technicalities of the matter are extreme. Interestingly, this morning when I was in a session of the conference of the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science a paper was presented by an American academic looking at the statistical basis of principles to deal with gerrymander following the Supreme Court judgment. The Supreme Court decided that it was a justifiable issue in the United States of America but that the particular case that was brought before it had not been proved to be an example of a gerrymander. The difficulties there are extreme in determining the various criteria that one may wish to use to identify a gerrymander and, secondly, in doing so, in determining whether on each of those criteria a particular drawing of boundaries is seen exclusively to be unfair.

SPEECH.PARA: My proposal in the Committee's hearing in Brisbane on 10 November last year was for an amendment to my Bill along the following lines:

The process of determining the boundaries of electoral divisions referred to in this section shall be based upon fair and non-partisan proceedings and criteria designed to ensure equal suffrage and free expression of the will of the electors.

That wording was an attempt to express a constitutional approach rather than a legislative approach. I depart from both the majority and, I presume, the minority of the Committee in regard to the following recommendation:
. . . the wording of Senator Macklin's proposed amendments to the 1987 Bill which aim to prevent the practice of gerrymandering are lacking in certainty.

That might be a statement of the obvious, but if anybody here is able to tell me of any part of the Constitution which is certain, I would be very interested. In the last debate on this matter I raised the issue of section 92, which deals with free trade between the States and which, when it was passed in the Constitutional Convention, was said to be at last an example of plain language. Yet the first High Court judgment, given by the first four High Court judges in the history of this country, all of whom had been in the room when that section passed the Constitutional Convention, was split 2:2. In other words, those four fathers of the Constitution were unable to agree on the meaning of section 92 relating to free trade between the States. I would have thought that that section might be said to lack certainty.

We have recently noted the sections of the Constitution dealing with the position of Senator Wood. Since the High Court adjourned to consider its verdict with regard to that matter, we have been canvassing amongst ourselves what might be the outcome. That case was not certain. No court cases, certainly in the High Court, are certain in that sense. So I find odd the suggestion that my proposed amendments to the Bill lack certainty. I would be the first to agree, but that does not seem to be anywhere near the point. I had hoped that they would be taken as an attempt to approach this area from a lateral viewpoint, from the point of view of attempting to write a constitutional provision rather than a legislative provision.

I could go through various other technical differences that I may have with the Committee; nevertheless, of the fundamental points I am very pleased that the majority of the Committee agreed that this is a serious item upon which the people of Australia should be asked their opinion. I remind Senator Short and other honourable senators who supported his comments that that is all that this Parliament is entitled to do. It is entitled only to put something to the people, to ask the people their view. I fail to see how this can be jack-booting. Asking the people their view is now described, in Senator Short's terms, as jack-booting. This is an extraordinary proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have already spent $6m trying to persuade them to that view. You have already spent $6m on propaganda of one kind or another.

—Senator Stone is again making inane comments from the corner from which he was previously giving directions to Senator Short-possibly the jack boot corner of the Senate. Senator Stone's proposition is an interesting one-that the people of Australia should not be asked their view on this matter. Section 128 of the Constitution was inserted at the very beginning to provide for the possibility of questions going to the people. Indeed, there will be another debate when we get to the four questions that I would hope might have the support of this chamber; that is, on the proposal for a constitutional initiative whereby the people themselves can put up questions as well. The more questions that go to the people, the better chance we have of determining what the people want as their Constitution.
—Then you would never have to make a hard decision on which side of the chamber to go to.

—In terms of constitutional amendments it is very clear on which side the Australian Democrats have been. On every occasion that such a proposal has come before this chamber we have supported it, whether or not we believed that we would support the item in question in a campaign. The reason that we have supported such proposals is that we believe that if they are bought forward and argued in a serious fashion, they ought to go to the people for their determination. We have been consistently of that view for the past 10 years and certainly since these questions have been before us in the past eight years during which we have held the balance of power in this chamber. We will continue to do so with the next four propositions, to come in the next two or three weeks. I believe that this item is of fundamental importance. The people of this country ought to have a chance to express their view on it. The people having expressed their view, it will then be either enshrined or not, as the case may be, and that will determine what goes on.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested that one of the honourable senators who were interjecting a little while ago was a member of the Liberal Party. I would counsel him to discuss this matter with his colleagues in Queensland. Mr Innes made the very good comment, I thought, that his Federal colleagues had no idea of what this was like because they did not live in Queensland and that if they went up there he would be able to give them some instructions on the matter. In fact, I understand that he has asked people who do not agree with this proposal to stay out of Queensland, because he is campaigning for it, as is the rest of the Liberal Party in Queensland.

I believe it is a crucial and very important decision that the Liberal Party in Queensland has made, because it means that the Liberal Party, the Labor Party and the Democrats will be supporting this issue very strongly. A large number of citizens committees across the State will be supporting this issue, and it is certainly my view, and I know that of members of both the Liberal Party and the Labor Party, that we should make Queensland the crucial State in relation to this proposal. It seems to me that the suggestion that is contained in both the majority and the minority reports that somehow the effluxion of time will solve the problem in Queensland does not really address the issue. As somebody said, we are not about to get a Steele Hall in Queensland; I can assure honourable senators of that. There are no wimps in the Queensland National Party; that was meant to be a derogatory, not a supportive, statement. In other words, it was suggested that principles are certainly not going to upset the hold of the National Party on power and it will stay there with as small a percentage as it can possibly organise which will deliver it the necessary seats.

I believe that it is not possible to stand aside from those circumstances. I think it is entirely appropriate and reasonable to put to the people of this country the proposition of whether they wish to have State elections run on the various boundaries and other systems that are involved. I remind honourable senators who are opposing this proposition of the very important history that Australia has had concerning electoral and constitutional reform. We have introduced the Australian ballot, as it is known in the United States of America-a secret ballot-and the vote for women. We made important advances step by step in the early years. Coming from Queensland, I am particularly buoyed by the fact that in 1899 there was a very strong campaign in Queensland to try to get a No vote for the entire Constitution. One of the reasons for the advocacy of a No vote at that time was that the Constitution did not entrench equal suffrage.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a long time ago.

—We have indeed fallen from that high pinnacle of grace, but I and the many other people in Queensland who I know are committed to this line will do all that we can to put Queensland in that majority of States when the final votes come in on the tally night in September.

SPEECH.PARA: Lastly, I would like to thank the Committee for the enormous amount of work that it undertook in looking at my Bill. I must admit that sometimes one feels somewhat guilty about these Bills going off to committee, particularly if it is a private member's Bill, because of the enormous amount of time that an investigation involves, even if a person involved in that process does not agree with an item in it.

In looking at the Committee's report, one notes the dedication to detail contained in it. Knowing as I do the enormous task that any senator in this place has in just finding time to go to a committee meeting, let alone getting down to the serious work of deliberation, I am very conscious of the amount of work that honourable senators have put into this report. I must admit that that guilt is somewhat assuaged by the fact that they were dealing with what I think is a very important issue. I am thankful that members of that Committee support the principle of putting this issue to the people. I thank members for that work, for their dedication and for the very interesting report. I have not yet had a chance to read it totally in detail.

I hope that the critical comments that I have made are not taken to mean that I am not appreciative of all the work that has been done. I believe that a great deal of material in the report will be very useful in the ensuing campaigns with regard to the Government's Bill. There are very little differences between the Government's Bill and the Bill that I introduced. There are some, of course. The Government has a starting date of 12 months, whereas I was leaving it to the High Court. The Government is seeking a number of other approaches; for example, the `as near as practicable' provision that I had in my Bill after the 10 per cent is not in the Government's Bill, but that is certainly in keeping with the Committee's report.

I am particularly pleased to see that the Government has supported the notion of individual voters having the right to initiate legal challenges, rather than leaving it to the Attorneys-General. The Government's view differs from that of the Committee in some sense in supporting the provisions with regard to a fall-back situation. I suppose the reason for that is that, while it seems fairly clear that in its deliberations the Committee may not have liked the proposition, there did not seem to be too many other ways of getting around the problem when finally coming to draft the proposal. There must be a fall-back situation when drafting a non-compliance provision and it should be made as unpalatable and unattractive as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it is.

—Senator Ray says that it is, and I am sure that probably Liberal Party senators would echo that sentiment. It is, and when I inserted it I was of the mind that it probably would be. Because it is unpalatable, it is something that the Commonwealth and the States would probably seek to avoid.

SPEECH.PARA: The last point I wish to make on this matter-and this differs from the points made by Ralph Hunt in a series of comments that appeared in the Australian yesterday-is that the power that will be installed in the Constitution, if the Government's Bill is accepted by the people, is a power that in future would be held by the people and not held by politicians. It would not be held by politicians of this Parliament or of the State Parliaments. I would have thought that closer attention to detail would have been given in terms of the arguments against the proposed measures than to suggest that in fact the Commonwealth would not be bound by this exercise but that the States would be. That is patently false in relation to the text of the Bill itself. The Commonwealth would lose the power to do anything about changing its electoral law, as would the States. Certainly the High Court would be involved. I am not sure how one would install a power in the Constitution which is held by the people without giving the High Court original jurisdiction to deliberate on items. I am not quite sure what the minority group was actually even suggesting by the proposition that somehow or other one had to deal with the High Court. Of course, the High Court must be the final arbiter with regard to the Constitution or any constitutional items that may go to litigation. I do not believe that the High Court will be politicised, any more than it was politicised when it was dealing with Senator Wood, or any more than it is politicised when dealing with the interminable issues with regard to the Constitution, all of which are of high political moment. Indeed, my political party took a case to the High Court, which it lost, with regard to the counting of votes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Evans v. Crichton- Browne.

—Yes, a case that we lost. Again, it was a matter on which the High Court was required to deliberate. The judges will get no more tangled up in matters that happen to be matters of political moment than might somehow be the case with murder because they happen to be deliberating on a murder trial. The whole idea of having the judicial system is for them to adjudicate. It is the adjudication that is the important item here. I believe that the High Court judges are quite capable of adjudicating on these items without becoming caught up in the day-to-day political process which has not occurred in any of the other processes over the past 87 years of Federation. I recommend this report to those people who are interested in this item. I am sure that the report will be widely read, appropriate as it is, during the next three or four months campaigning that will be necessary with regard to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. First, I must say that it was a considerable pleasure to be asked by my Party to nominate to serve on this Joint Parliamentary Committee. I also pay tribute to the work done by the now Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, as Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. I believe that in many ways the groundwork for the standing of this Joint Standing Committee and for the work it is now doing was laid in the previous parliament by the excellent contribution of Senator Robert Ray.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also pleased to speak in this debate because I come from a State that I think set the trend for the achievement of one vote one value in Australia or fair and equitable elections. When I joined the Australian Labor Party in 1965 in South Australia, the Labor Party won the election that year after 33 years in opposition, with a two-party preferred vote of 57 per cent, and we won narrowly by two seats. In 1968, we still got a two-party preferred vote of 56 per cent but we lost the election because a handful of votes changed in two small rural electorates. In first preference terms, the Liberal Party of Australia got only about 41 per cent of the vote.

As a person in my early twenties just joining the Party and becoming active in politics, I do not think I have ever felt a greater sense of unfairness on election night than I felt in 1968 to have a government defeated, when clearly tens of thousands of South Australian citizens voted for the Labor Party to be the government only to have the election result stolen unfairly by a crook electoral system that had been operating in South Australia for over 30 years.

I certainly have considerable pleasure in the fact that the first report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters to be tabled should deal with the fundamental issue of one vote one value-fair elections. I believe that South Australians and, in fact, all Australians would have to pay tribute to a politician from South Australia who did more than anyone else to raise the agenda of political reform on fair elections-Don Dunstan. Through the late 1960s and early 1970s, when I was first active in politics, Don Dunstan never let up whenever he had an opportunity to explain that we will not get fair, decent, honest government unless we have fair, decent, honest electoral boundaries. He made the point that the citizens will be ignored and there will be corrupt government if governments are elected by the minority of the people, whereby the party in government believes that at any time it can thumb its nose at the electorate because it knows that, despite what the majority votes, it will always be in government.

That is the problem in Queensland today-after 30 years, there is a corrupt government. At present, in Queensland there is the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct. It is bringing to light for the public the most bizarre circumstances of the Police Commissioner in Queensland saying in his diary that he has been discussing with politicians the redistribution of Queensland electoral boundaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going to set up the same commission in South Australia?

—I inform Senator Stone that in any other State that Police Commissioner would be laughed out of the State and sent overseas. It is extraordinary that it could be acceptable behaviour that a police commissioner could have a direct say in the drawing up of electoral boundaries in any State.
—Nobody is condoning that.

—I point out to Senator Stone that the reason that it occurs in Queensland is that the Government from the Party to which the honourable senator belongs has accepted that as a standard way of acting in a political sense because it knows that, come the next election, the malapportionment of boundaries will still put it back in office. The Government was elected, even though it received only 39 per cent of the vote in first preference terms at the last election.

—The question that I put to you, Senator, is: When are you going to set up in South Australia the equivalent of the Fitzgerald Commission, and follow the excellent lead of the Queensland Government in doing so?

—I must say that, under any parallel observation, if the honourable senator is suggesting that the South Australian Police Force is as corrupt as that bunch in Queensland or that we have in South Australia Ministers who are into every type of take and bribe such as exists in Queensland-whether it be the present Labor Government or the Tonkin Liberal Government of 1979 to 1982-he is living in a fantasy world. I know that Senator Stone has a very difficult time in defending the absurd and corrupt behaviour of his parliamentary colleagues in the National Party in Queensland. However, he should not try to pull our legs by saying that other States are as bad as his; they are not.

SPEECH.PARA: When Don Dunstan was campaigning for one vote one value, he made it quite clear that there was a need to have fair boundaries and the right of ordinary citizens to be able to get the government that they wanted. This sentiment is summed up in recommendation 1.14 of the report of the Joint Committee about the rights of the individual as against the rights of the Government. That recommendation states:
the Federal Government has a clear responsibility to act to overcome this infringement-
that is, the infringement of malapportionment-
of the individual rights of Australian electors to have an equal say in choosing their governments and that the Federal Government therefore has a responsibility to introduce one vote, one value.
I know that there was a dissenting report by four senators, including Liberal Party of Australia and National Party of Australia senators. What an extraordinary dissenting report it is when it says:
The proposal will not ensure fair and democratic elections.

Whatever the deficiencies in one vote one value, they are minuscule compared with the deficiencies of malapportionment and gerrymander that exist in States such as Queensland. Whatever the deficiencies in one vote one value, by and large they will be overcome by appointing an independent electoral commission.

In South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria independent electoral commissions have been established by legislation with clear sets of criteria for drawing up electoral boundaries on the basis of one vote one value with a 10 per cent tolerance. In each case the boundaries drawn have stood the test of time. When a majority of people have voted against the incumbent government of the day that government has been tossed out, whether the South Australian Labor Government in 1979, the South Australian Liberal Government in 1982 or the Unsworth Labor Government this year in New South Wales.

When a clear majority of people have voted in two-party preferred terms-50 per cent plus one for one party-the fair electoral boundaries have delivered the government for which the majority voted. That does not happen in Queensland. It can happen by accident in Western Australia, although there is malapportionment in that State and, of course, the situation with the upper House in Tasmania is a bizarre example of non-electoral democracy. The report of the Joint Committee points out deficiencies; it does not hide them. There are some deficiencies theoretically about one vote one value, but where it has operated in Australia in recent times the people have got the government for which they have voted.

I do not wish to talk for too long about Senator Macklin's Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill 1987. I believe that some form of congratulation must go to Senator Macklin for introducing a private member's Bill. Other members of parliament have put forward proposals by way of private members' Bills. You Mr Acting Deputy President, had a proposal for one vote one value to overcome the problem in your home State. Many proposals have been talked about and Senator Macklin was one honourable senator who brought a proposal into this Parliament.

However, the Joint Committee made it clear that, after thorough examination, it had decided that Senator Macklin's Bill was quite deficient. The reasons for that are exposed in the report and I will not go into detail. Certainly, Senator Macklin had great difficulty in trying to work out how all the details to ensure fair and equitable distribution of electoral boundaries can be included in the Constitution. First, he used the phrase `as near as practicable', and it was clear that that phrase could be open to an enormous number of definitions and interpretations. Senator Macklin then referred to a maximum of 10 per cent but, in trying to outline 10 per cent, he made a most convoluted proposal that, again, would have been a lawyer's delight, leading to argument before the High Court of Australia about exactly what it meant. By accident, it would have meant that on a number of occasions we would have had many elections at large in either the State or Federal sphere, and that would not have been in the interests of good government. This matter is referred to by the Committee in recommendation 1.24:
It would be a backward step to introduce a voting system which would lead to the election of minority governments dependent on minor parties holding the balance of power in a lower House.

That would be the result if there were elections at large under any system. There have been a couple of elections at large in the Western world, and one was in my own State of South Australia in 1901 when the boundaries were not drawn up in time for the first Federal election. So there was an election at large in that State before the proper party system was created and there were some unusual results. There was an even more classic case in the State of Illinois in the United States of America in 1968 when that State could not meet the requirements of the Supreme Court on one vote one value; so all 120 members of the House of Representatives of the State Parliament of Illinois had an election at large thrust on them at the very last moment. It was a first past the post system and it was an absolute nightmare for political parties, for candidates to know how many votes they required and so on. The Committee looked at this and found that it would be an intolerable burden. I note that Senator Coulter also accepted recommendation 1.24 about the difficulty in minority parties having a balance of power in the lower House and what that would obviously do to good and effective government.

I will address a few remarks to the 10 per cent tolerance recommended in the report. Of course, this refers to the Government Bill for a referendum which is to come here from the other place. A 10 per cent tolerance is an effective and practical margin to allow for any electorate in Australia whether Federal, State or territorial. It is not beyond the wit of men and women these days with modern electoral enrolment to use a 10 per cent tolerance. As a State party secretary in South Australia I had the opportunity on a number of occasions to prepare the ALP submission to the independent Electoral Commission in that State using the 10 per cent tolerance. It is not difficult to have reasonably defined boundaries using appropriate geographical or topographical markings that are well known in the community to form a boundary. One of the arguments put here is that this does not overcome the problem of gerrymandering.

Certainly in a theoretical sense gerrymandering cannot be stopped by having only a 10 per cent tolerance, but it is substantially and significantly reduced. I will cite a couple of examples, the first being in the 1970s in South Australia when I tried to draw up a redistribution proposal which gave a maximum number of seats to the Liberal Party based on voting patterns for that Party and another scenario giving a maximum number of seats to the Labor Party based on its voting patterns. I found for both scenarios that a boundary can certainly be fiddled in a particular area to give either the Liberal Party or Labor Party more of a margin in any particular seat. However, I quickly discovered that because of the overriding 10 per cent tolerance the domino falls down the map somewhere else and what either the Liberal Party or the ALP may gain in one corner of the city in trying to gerrymander it loses somewhere else. The overriding 10 per cent tolerance makes it extremely difficult to gerrymander in the classic sense of Governor Gerry in Massachusetts some 150 years ago, in the Queensland example with its zonal system under the present National Party Government or in South Australia under the zonal system that operated during the days of Sir Thomas Playford.

TALK.START.PARA: —His was with equal votes. You have just bombed your own arguments.

—It is extremely difficult to rig the boundaries in the sense of a gerrymander. The other thing that should be mentioned is that it is expected that independent commissioners will be appointed under the Act-an independent surveyor-general and an independent judge-unlike Queensland where a couple of cockies are selected from the National Party to be on an electoral boundaries commission to carry out the political instructions of the Premier of the day. SPEECH.PARA: I look forward to the forthcoming campaign on the referendum in Australia. People like Mr Hall have made it quite clear that they support one vote one value, as do Mr Moore, the President of the Liberal Party in Queensland and front bench member, and Mr Innes. I look forward to strife within the Liberal Party as it tries to wriggle off the hook that it has put itself on in relation to this issue. The Liberal Party and its Leader made a fundamental mistake in that they tried to achieve coalition unity by opposing all the referendum questions, but in particular one vote one value, to appease the rednecks in the National Party. TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters report but some of the matters put to the Senate by Senator Schacht in particular I think simply cannot be allowed to pass without at least some brief comment. Indeed, I will also comment on some of the remarks made by Senator Macklin who unfortunately has left the chamber. Whatever may or may not be said against or in favour of those electoral arrangements we should be clear about one or two facts. One fact about which we should be quite clear is that as I understand it-and I base this on the work of political scientists such as Mr Malcolm Mackerras and Dr Dean Jaensch-under the present electoral arrangements in Queensland the Australian Labor Party (ALP) would need to win 51.4 per cent of the total vote in that State in order to gain a majority in the lower House.
—Surely they have to win 50 per cent plus one vote to win.

—If Senator Schacht will contain his impatience I will respond to his intemperate interjection in a moment. I am developing my first point. In fact, the Queensland branch of the ALP has not come within a bull's roar of winning even 50 per cent of the vote. I think its highest vote for donkey's years has been something of the order of 42 per cent of the electorate; so what is all the fuss about? What are all the cries of pain from the ALP as to the adverse effects for that party under the voting arrangements in Queensland? I find it quite surprising and, indeed, interesting that the ALP should put itself forward as what appears to be the champion of the Liberal Party of Australia in Queensland. That appears to be the only possible logical explanation for taking up this issue. I think that we should be quite clear that that is what is at the root of the matter. We are talking about a situation in which government in Queensland could change if the ALP was up to the task of gaining 51.4 per cent of the vote in that State. That is the hallmark of the failure of the Australian Labor Party in the State of Queensland. Let us have that quite clearly on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us compare that situation for example with one which confronted the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia at the election held in New South Wales on 19 March last. TALK.START.PARA: —It is only 51 per cent in Queensland, is it not?

—In order to achieve the same result in Queensland, the Labor Party had to get 51.4 per cent of the vote. So what is all this wringing of hands by Senator Schacht all about? For the sake of completeness, I add that we are discussing these so-called one vote one value deliberations of the Committee report that we are considering against the background of a set of referendum proposals being brought forward by the present Labor Government in Canberra, one of which is the proposal in favour of so-called fair and democratic elections, unspecified. Yet this is being done by a party which is presiding over a situation where the conservative parties in this country will also have to obtain about 52.5 per cent of the vote at the next election in order to gain office. Those on the other side of this chamber and the other place are a bunch of hypocrites who accuse the Queensland National Party amongst others, but more generally the conservative parties-the Liberal and National parties; the Opposition parties in this place-of being against fairness and democracy in the electoral procedures. SPEECH.PARA: I want to make one or two brief remarks about Senator Macklin's speech, which was made a little while ago. In particular, Senator Macklin raised a point which I think requires a little calm reflection-not the kind of political speech that he made on the subject-on the role of the High Court in these matters. As Senator Macklin indicated when introducing his remarks on this subject, it is true that one of the objections which people on this side of the chamber have to the proposals brought forward by the Government in the four referendums Bills is that they will place a great deal more power in the hands of an unelected body of people who sit in that ghastly building near the lake to adjudicate upon what precisely is meant by certain words which, if these Bills were to be passed, would become part of our written Constitution and would then become justiciable-which, I think, is the word used by the lawyers, of whom I am not one. Senator Macklin went on to castigate those who he alleged were accusing the justices of our High Court of having become politicised. I say quite dispassionately that I am not aware of anyone, from our side of politics at least, who thinks about our High Court justices as being politicised.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know Barwick's letter of resignation was dated 1974, with the ink still wet in 1981.

—Judging by the momentary and intemperate interjection of Senator Walsh, there appear to be some honourable senators on the other side of this chamber who are prone to that kind of ill-judged accusation. Nevertheless, let me go on; I refuse to be diverted in that way. What is at the heart of the disquiet-I even go so far as to say increasing disquiet-on the part of many sober, objective, detached and dispassionate observers of our judicial scene in Australia today is a feeling that what we now have is a High Court composed of people with a highly centralist view of the way in which government in Australia should operate. That is not the same as a politicised view and it is not the same as suggesting political attachment, affiliation or anything of that kind. It is a view which purports to attach a certain view of the way in which things are best done within our Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the opposite view is what one might call the decentralist view, the devolutionist view, or what used to be called the federalist view-and that is still a very respectable title for that view. What has led to what I believe to be the increasing disquiet on this matter has been a whole series of judicial developments within the decisions of the High Court flowing over the course of the past, let us say, 10 years or so-I do not want to be too precise about it. First of all we had the extraordinary-perhaps even stronger words might be justified-development of the interpretation of the external affairs power of the Constitution. When we went to school or wherever we learnt anything at all about the Constitution, we had a view about the external affairs power. The Commonwealth had that power which enabled it to enter into external affairs policy questions and other matters of that kind.

We have seen the development of a series of cases in the High Court over the past decade or so in this matter which has meant a total rewriting of that normally conceived view of the external power with which we all grew up. The most notable-and I would almost say notorious-case of that kind was, of course, the Franklin dams case. I do not want to spend time on particular cases, but I simply want to remark that as a consequence of this we now have a situation where if the government of the day-it could be a government of any political persuasion-were to seek to bend the external affairs power to its will in order to get its own way on some particular matter, then, given a certain lead time in order to allow it to undertake the necessary international negotiations and find an appropriate country with which to make a treaty about an appropriate subject, it would be able to do so.
In addition, we have had the development of the corporations power, starting with, if I recall correctly, the Rocla Pipes case years ago when I was still in the Federal Treasury--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone, we are debating a report which was brought down on electoral matters, so I hope you will tie some of your comments, however interesting they may be, to that report.

—I will certainly try to do that, Mr Acting Deputy President, if for no other reason than out of respect for your presence in the chair. I had hoped that I had begun to do so by my initial reference to the fact that I was commenting on the remarks made earlier in the debate this evening by Senator Macklin when he was referring to what he called the views of people on this side of the chamber about the politicisation of the High Court and its possible role, in an interpretative sense, in relation to the one vote one value referendum. I hope that I can continue to cleave to that line of discussion. Recently the High Court made an extraordinary decision-one might say that it was almost revolutionary-in relation to section 92, the so-called interstate trade and commerce power, which, if I recall correctly, is supposed to be absolutely free. Those are the exact words-`absolutely free'. While I am not a lawyer, my understanding is that the High Court's recent decision in that matter has totally reversed everything which most people thought they knew about the interpretation of that power for the past 50 or 60 years. Moreover, that decision was not made on the basis of some narrow majority, as I think the original external affairs power decision might have been made, but on the basis of unanimity on the part of the Bench. The Bench has suddenly turned round 180 degrees and charged off in the opposite direction in relation to section 92.

SPEECH.PARA: It is those centralist notions to which, I repeat, people of goodwill in the community are directing their attention when they are expressing a sense of disquiet-I would add, a growing disquiet-about the trend and tendency of decisions emanating from the highest court in our land. It is that disquiet which has given rise to the concern of many people on our side of politics when they confront the prospect of four referendum Bills, one of which is the one vote one value Bill which is the subject of the report before us tonight, which, should they be approved at what I take it will be the forthcoming referendum, will write into our Constitution more words to be interpreted in the future by bodies of unelected people sitting on the Bench of our High Court. That is a prospect which begins to fill people with increasing dismay, particularly when one comes to matters such as-this is not so much the one vote one value area-the freedom of religion and so on.

The one vote one value matter cannot be separated, in this context at least, from the referendum proposal which is currently before the House of Representatives and which no doubt will come into this chamber next week. Therefore, it must be considered in the context of the three other proposals. The fact of the matter is that the Australian Labor Party is in trouble. It has had a smashing defeat in the New South Wales elections and a series of by-election defeats. Australia's balance of payments is in a mess. Only last Thursday the Treasurer (Mr Keating) confessed at the Premiers Conference, for the first time, that the improvement in the balance of payments this year was fortuitous-that is his word which I quote-that the inflation rate was beginning to rise again and, therefore, put a cat among the trade union pigeons whom he had been so carefully stroking for some time.

It is a document, as has been indicated, which will be worth while for persons interested in this subject to have on their library shelves and to study. I must say that, although I was present for most, if not all, of the hearings on this reference, because of the burdens of another committee, which shall remain nameless, I was not able to be present for most of the private deliberations that took place on this Committee. Therefore, I do not include myself in my congratulatory remarks. However, I do observe that much of the debate that has taken place tonight has focused on the individual States of those honourable senators who have taken part in the debate. One would sense that there was a pervading atmosphere of State of Origin around the place tonight. I would suspect that, for example, if Senator Michael Baume were to call a quorum-I sincerely hope that he does not-the sense of State of Origin would prevail even outside this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: As a senator from the State of Tasmania I want to say something about the criterion of one vote one value. It will be observed by those honourable senators who have read the Committee report that on the criterion of one vote one value Tasmania's Legislative Assembly comes out best in the David-Eisenberg index for Australian legislatures. However, on the basis of that same criterion of one vote one value, Tasmania's Legislative Council comes out worst on that particular index. Honourable senators might thus ask why I signed the minority report. I did so because I indicated that for a fair electoral process which is designed in the interests of representative parliaments and governments the criterion of one vote one value is but one criterion to be considered amongst a whole range of others.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not intend to transgress your ruling as to what those other criteria might be or to get into the question of referenda and so forth. However, I feel that it is necessary to point out that there are other factors which need to be taken into consideration, namely, the question of who is eligible to vote and what the population basis is for the electorate-whether it is to be based on the number of electors or the number of people in the electorate. That is a question that we have not faced. However, that is very important when we have to consider the question of one vote one value. We have to ask why electorates are not decided federally on the basis of how many people are in those electorates. Is the person who is elected to the Parliament to represent only the electors or is that person to represent every man, woman and child in that electorate? I feel very strongly about this question. I do not go to the extent of saying that the value of a person's vote should be equal to the number of people dependent on his or her wage. However, I do say that it would certainly smarten up a few people in regard to their family policies or otherwise if the electorate were based on the number of people rather than the number of voters. That is something that should be given mature consideration by the Parliament. I believe that it is conceded generally that there are other situations that the question of one vote one value does not address. It addresses only the question of malapportionment. It does not address the question of gerrymander. When considerations of gerrymander come into account then we must look at the question of community of interest. It is said that this is not a matter that is able to be taken into account at this stage. However, I think that if we are looking at the whole of this area perhaps it is something that ought to be taken into account. It was interesting to note that when we held public hearings in Queensland on the Macklin Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill, one of the complaints made by the Australian Labor Party-one of the major parties that came before us-was that legislation was rammed through the Legislative Assembly in Queensland. There was the complaint of procedures being followed in that House which made proper consideration of legislation quite difficult. Surely the answer to that is not one vote one value but to have a House of review, a legislative council or something like that. I am not suggesting that there should be more politicians. Far be it from me to suggest more politicians.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are far too many in Tasmania.

—Senator Walsh has interjected. It was Senator Walsh and his Government that proposed an increase in the number of Federal politicians by about 40. He wanted 40 more politicians. We are paying for it. I do not know how much that will eventually cost the taxpayers of this country but it will cost a mighty lot. However, if proper procedures and the ramming through of legislation are a problem, that is a matter for those procedures or for a House of review. It is not overcome by the institution of one vote one value. I make the qualifying statement here, although I have not written it in the minority report, that there is an argument for and I consider it desirable that in a legislature in which the Government is actually formed a greater emphasis should be placed on the criterion of one vote one value. I am concerned however that in my State of Tasmania if the principle of one vote one value were adopted for the Legislative Council certain people in isolated areas in the State with a firm community of interest would not have a politician representing them who also lived in that area. For example, if the seat of Gordon on the west coast of Tasmania, a clearly defined area of community interest, were to be placed into some other area because of the operation of the system of one vote one value, where would it go? Would it go east, over the mountains, or would it go north, to the north-west coast? One of the problems in Tasmania is rugged terrain and poor accessibility. That exercised my mind as well when giving this matter consideration. Substantial work has been done on this.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel there will be a need for me to address a number of issues during the second reading and committee stage debates on the referendum Bills and I do not intend to say anything further on that. I would simply like to add one more comment. I believe we should acknowledge what Senator Macklin has done in this regard. I know when one has to develop a Bill such as this one needs to do an enormous amount of reading and devote an enormous amount of one's time to backgrounding oneself in order to prepare for debate. Consideration has to be given to the type of words that may be needed here or there to make the legislation accurate. Senator Macklin's work should be acknowledged because it is important that this issue of one vote one value be put on the table for discussion. Though Senator Macklin has given me and the rest of the Committee a fair bit of work to do, nevertheless his work should be given due acknowledgment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The one vote one value proposal will not ensure fair and democratic elections. That is the essence of the minority report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters tabled today, and that is the issue that the Australian Labor Party simply will not face up to and continually ducks.
—What is the Liberal Party saying in Queensland, Patrick?

—There is the Minister for gutters again, who cannot properly address this chamber even by way of interjection without becoming offensive-or is it tired and emotional?
