—Order! Senator Baume, I did not pull you up the first time but I think that is a most inappropriate term to use. I am not asking you to withdraw it but I do ask you not to use that term again.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. If your suggestion encourages the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to keep quiet for a change and to contribute properly any serious points he may have, your involvement may be useful. I thank you for it. The reality is that the Labor Party has sought, dishonestly and dishonourably, to convey an impression that by pursuing this goal of one vote one value it will somehow magically generate fair elections. That is an absolute basic untruth. Senator Schacht, who mouthed this nonsense, knows that only too well. After all, Senator Schacht is the person who, on his own admission, was basically behind the preparation of Labor Party proposals for South Australian redistributions. Now I understand why on the average for the last five years South Australia has the most grossly unfair voting system of any State in Australia. We can discern that very simply by seeing what proportion of the votes is required for the other side to win.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Harradine quite rightly said, the gerrymander effect relates not necessarily to one vote one value but to the way we design electorates. It is the design of electorates that creates gerrymanders, and we have heard from Senator Schacht's own mouth of his contribution to the gerrymander in South Australia. Over the last five years the index bias in South Australia has averaged 4.9 per cent. What is the average bias in Queensland over the past five years? It is 1.5 per cent-the lowest of any State apart from Tasmania, which has a different voting system. Queensland has the lowest bias factor of any of the mainland States and South Australia, where Senator Schacht contributes to the redistribution process, has the worst. So what sort of humbug, what sort of dishonesty, do we have in this chamber from the Labor Party?

Senator Schacht also said that any deficiencies in other States are far less than those of the Queensland gerrymander. Yet South Australia has a system almost three times as biased, because of the design of its boundaries, as Queensland's. So let us examine what Senator Schacht is prepared to tell this chamber-and in so doing mislead it-about the reality of gerrymanders. He quite improperly suggested that gerrymanders can be reduced by reducing malapportionment. Malapportionment is what we have in Queensland, where there are electorates of vastly different sizes. But there is a major difference between having electorates of vastly different sizes and having a system, as Senator Stone said, which results in an unfair count at the end of the day. As Senator Schacht says, gerrymanders can be reduced by reducing malapportionment, but the reality is that they can also be increased by reducing malapportionment. In other words, malapportionment does not dictate in any way, and on the experience of Australian elections has no relationship with, the gerrymander factor in Australian elections both State and Federal.

Of course Senator Schacht also misled the Parliament about Governor Elbridge Gerry of Massachusetts, who signed a Bill in 1811 creating new electoral districts to favour the Republican Party. I quote this from the report, which Senator Schacht obviously has not even read:
One of the districts was in the shape of a salamander and as a result the term `gerrymander' was coined to refer to the drawing of electoral boundaries which ensured bias towards one party or person.

In the report the diagram which illustrates what a gerrymander is all about uses exactly the same numbers of voters on either side and demonstrates that, even though the voters are equally divided between the two parties, the first figure shows that boundaries can be drawn to give three seats to the `X' group and one to the `O' group, while the other figure shows that this result can be completely reversed to give the `O' group three seats and the `X' group one seat. The essence of the gerrymander relates to the drawing of boundaries. That is why, when Senator Schacht promised to instruct the chamber on what was a gerrymander, he either did not know what he was talking about or deliberately set out to deceive the chamber. He did one or the other and he can have whichever he likes. The report says:

While malapportionment may be removed by creating electorates with equal numbers of voters, electoral boundaries may still be drawn so as to advantage a party or person. A gerrymander may be achieved with entirely equal electorates, that is with equal numbers of voters in each electorate.
Is that not quaint? That is from the report. But what does Mr Lee say in his tabling statement? He seeks once again to mislead the Parliament by claiming something totally different. He says:
The Committee notes in its report that the achievement of one vote, one value does not stop the possibility of gerrymandering, but is a necessary first step for fair and democratic elections.

That is utter bunkum. There is no defence of that proposition. In fact, the results of recent years show it to be totally false and I will illustrate that from the results of recent years in the States. For example, as I said, South Australia has the worst bias of any State as a result of the drawing of boundaries. A table which I have shows that in 1973 South Australia had a 9.3 per cent bias, in 1975 a 7 per cent bias, in 1977 a 9.3 per cent bias, and in 1979 magically only a 0.5 per cent bias. Of course, these biases were all in favour of the Australian Labor Party. Then there was a 5.5 per cent bias and an 8.2 per cent bias. If one takes the average over the last five elections one ends up with just under a 5 per cent bias as against a 1.5 per cent bias in Queensland. The bias in New South Wales in 1981 was 6.1 per cent. It is fascinating to note that in 1981, when New South Wales had an enormous 6.1 per cent bias, it was also the closest to one vote one value of any of the States of Australia or the Federal Parliament. Here we have a situation which clearly dramatises the historical reality that one vote one value led in 1981 to the worst case of electoral bias in Australia. This is what happened in New South Wales after, of course, a Labor redistribution. This is the consistent pattern throughout Australia that the Labor Party has created with the phoney approach which it maintains of one vote one value solving all of the problems with the democratic voting system. It has continually created the real and genuine gerrymander within that phoney environment-the one which in fact can and generally does take place within electorates of equal size.

It is interesting to look at the other States. In Victoria there has been a 3.3 per cent bias over the last five elections-more than double that of Queensland. In New South Wales there has been a bias of 4.7 per cent, in South Australia 4.9 per cent, which as I said is the record, in Western Australia 3.5 per cent and in Australia as a whole 3.7 per cent. In New South Wales the Liberals had to get 52.4 per cent or so-in fact, on my figures it is 52.8 per cent-to win. There is disagreement about that, Senator Stone, but it is in the area of 52.4 to 52.8 per cent. The Liberals in South Australia need 52.2 per cent to win. Federally, the latest figure is that 52.5 per cent is needed to win. Yet here we have a situation where the Labor Party has sought to pretend that by approaching closer to the principle of one vote one value it has somehow saved democracy. It has saved democracy by in fact making the voting system more and more unfair.

Quite frankly, I am of the view-and I have to say so-that I would prefer to see a fair system which did not incorporate gerrymanders but which got closer to one vote one value. I do not say that one should necessarily reach such an objective because, as Senator Harradine said, there are other factors which can well be taken into consideration. Senator Harradine made the sensible point that perhaps the system should be based on the people in the electorate and not necessarily on voters. Are not children being represented in this place? Perhaps that factor could be looked at. I believe that we face a real risk if we go along the track that this report sets out. If we allow voters in New South Wales to dictate to the voters in Western Australia or anywhere else how they should manage their affairs, I believe that we will be going down the track towards the sort of authoritarian dictatorial government that the socialists of this nation continually support. Here we have a situation in which the Labor Party wants the voters of New South Wales, who have had to suffer an average bias of 4.3 per cent, to dictate to the voters of Queensland, which has had an average bias of 1.5 per cent, and to say to them that somehow they should change their system more towards the New South Wales pattern. What absolute bunkum! Yet this is the sort of rubbish that we are going to hear over and over again in the next few months. Why should the voters of New South Wales have the right to dictate to Queens- landers or anyone else how they should conduct their election system? Quite frankly, if Queens- landers do not like their election system, they can vote against it. If Labor senators are silly enough to interject--

TALK.START.PARA: —A gerrymandered system.

—Ah, Senator Cook is silly enough to interject. He has just led with what loosely can be described as a glass jaw. It was a `come in sucker'. I thank Senator Cook. The reality is that if the Queenslanders do not like it they can vote it out by 51.5 per cent of them on average voting against it. By comparison, 53 per cent of the people of New South Wales would have to vote against their system if they did not like it. But in Queensland, because the system in that State has a bias on average of only 1.5 per cent, a majority of far fewer people would be needed to change the Government. The reality is this: the people of Queensland have the democratic right to change their electoral system, which is far less biased than the one in New South Wales and certainly far less biased than the one that Senator Schacht has done his damnedest to create into the worst bias on average over the last five elections of any State in Australia.
—You have to admit there is a very heavy price there-you have to vote Labor to do that.

—Perhaps that would be a problem in Queensland. Maybe Senator Stone has just demolished the argument. But the reality is that if people in the States do not like their electoral system, the democratic and proper way to go about fixing it is to vote through their State elections to change it. What sanctimonious rubbish do we hear from the Government which is perpetuating a situation through the Senate? There is no one vote one value in the Senate. Maybe that is why many of the Labor Party people want to abolish the Senate. Obviously, the federal system incorporates the Senate arrangement under which a vote in Tasmania is worth far more than a vote in New South Wales. Is it not appalling that Senator Cook's vote in Western Australia is more important than mine in New South Wales? It carries more weight. Heaven knows why; it cannot be on an intellectual index. Present company on this side of the chamber is excepted from that remark.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that this report endorses the concept of differential voting power. It says that the present Senate system should be maintained because this is a historical compromise. How can this historical compromise be acceptable when other historical compromises relating to other upper Houses in, say, Tasmania and Western Australia are somehow unacceptable when they have different values? The simple point that emerges is that there has been a smokescreen, an absolutely dishonourable attempt to create a phoney impression, firstly, that we will solve all problems relating to election fairness by having one vote one value, which is bunkum. The disgraceful conclusion of the majority report is as follows:
. . . the Committee has concluded that the Federal Government has a clear responsibility to act to overcome what the Committee views-
that should read, `the majority of the Committee views'-
as an infringement of the individual rights of Australian electors to have an equal say in choosing their governments.

I will not tolerate and would certainly vote against any Canberra politician or Canberra bureaucrat who sought to impose on me in my home State how I should vote and the system under which I should vote in my State elections. If I do not like the way the State elections of the New South Wales are run, I can vote Liberal, and I did. As a result of that election, the New South Wales electoral laws are to be fixed up. The Labor Party introduced the nonsensical optional preferential voting system which was aimed at destroying, unfairly and deliberately, the capacity of the coalition to oppose Labor candidates in Labor held seats. That, of course, was dishonourable and members of the Labor Party found, quaintly, that they were the biters bitten. The independents who stood in the coal seats in the areas of Newcastle and Wollongong on the south coast and so on, devastated the faction ridden, arrogant, out of touch Labor members of those areas. They have demonstrated that that optional preferential system can bite its parents.

TALK.START.PARA: —The preferences did not flow.

—As Senator Stone says, the preferences did not flow and Labor members were beaten in a magnificent landslide. That is the way to change a lousy electoral system-to vote the Government out. That is what has happened in New South Wales. That is why we are going to get rid of the ludicrous bias in New South Wales, where the average bias factor over the last five elections was 4.3 per cent, almost three times the Queensland electoral bias.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to this House and to the Labor Party: if Labor continues to reveal the extent to which it is out of touch by trying to dictate to various States, particularly the smaller ones, how those States and their voters should conduct their electoral process-if it keeps trying to dictate from Canberra in its out of touch ivory tower in the way it has on almost every other issue-it will be doomed at the next election. If the people of Queensland and the people of Western Australia-which, by the way, has a bigger bias than Queensland-want to change their electoral system, all they have to do is follow the lead of New South Wales and vote out the authoritarian type governments which try to fiddle the electoral process by giving lip service to the principle of fairness by saying they support one vote one value and who then sneakily, through the back door, do what they can to ensure that the electoral boundaries are so ludicrous that it takes a major swing for those in opposition to achieve a minor victory.

That is what this Labor Government is all about. This is a deliberate and dishonourable campaign to put up a smokescreen. God knows what the motives are. Senator Stone said that the Roman circus is trying to put on a diversion. I believe that it is more sinister than that. I believe this is part of the Labor Party's general pattern of doing what it can ultimately to destabilise and destroy the power of this Senate to be a genuine House of review. The Australian Democrats, who have a particular interest in this issue, should recognise the pattern of attack on this institution. We should remember at all times that, if it had not been for this institution, the ID card would have been passed into law--

TALK.START.PARA: —So would the Bill of Rights.

—And the so-called Bill of Rights would have passed into law. This Government will stop at nothing, I believe, to impose its authoritarian will on the people of Australia. It is now once again trying to impose on the people of the various States its view of how their elections should be conducted. Yet we know perfectly well from every bit of evidence that one vote one value does not guarantee fair and democratic elections. On the contrary, those Labor States where there is a much closer relationship to one vote one value than in other States have the biggest bias factor, because of the gerrymander of boundaries, of anywhere in Australia.

—That is a ludicrous proposition. Labor has been in government in the House of Assembly in Western Australia but has never controlled the Legislative Council because of bias from the past. It is bias by the conservatives.

—Senator Cook's only excuse is either that he came into the chamber too late to hear the realities of the figures from all the States which show South Australia as having the worst bias, or he has a curious inability to understand the simplest of English words-and I fear it is the latter. I fear that it is because of an inability to comprehend. It could, of course, be a deliberate attempt to mislead the Australian people, as he will try to do later no doubt.
—That is what the Government has been doing for months.

—Exactly. Just as Senator Schacht came in here and deliberately set out to mislead us, so has Senator Cook, in the knowledge-because I have given it to him-that in the last five elections in South Australia the average bias as a result of a gerrymander was 4.9 per cent. In other words, those on the other side have to get that much more of a vote to get into power. Senator Cook knows that, yet he maintains the same dishonourable rubbish that we will hear throughout--
—Why do we support one vote one value and you oppose it?

—He supports one vote one value because in that way he can pretend that he is supporting the principle of fairer elections. We have seen from all the statistics not only that there is no correlation between one vote one value and a fair election but also that those Labor States which have been closer to one vote one value have had the most disgraceful and extreme unfair bias factors. I have given poor dear Senator Cook all the facts and he is still incapable of understanding them. That is his problem; but the people of Australia will understand them only too well. They understand the crooked way in which people like Senator Schacht in his previous role sought to influence the South Australian redistribution commission so that South Australia, on average, has the greatest bias in terms of electoral procedures of any State in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude simply by saying that we have heard from these two great intellects of the Labor Party, Senator Schacht and Senator Cook, a sort of microcosm, if you like, of the kind of rubbish that we will hear during the run-up to the referenda. We have heard that there will be no reliance on fact or analysis of history. We will simply hear the non-stop parrot-like and mindless repetition of advocacy of one vote one value, as if that is going to solve the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you oppose it? That is the democratic way: Why do you oppose it? Stop weaving and ducking and just say why you oppose it.

—The reality is that Senator Cook will mindlessly go on out in the electorate in the way that he has gone on here today. But I can assure Senator Cook that the people of Australia are capable of understanding the facts and the reality of the situation. The reality is, as the minority report says, that the one vote one value system does not ensure fair and democratic elections; in fact, in Labor States it almost ensures that there will not be fair and democratic elections. Of course, the genuine gerrymander, the one that Labor States are expert at, is in relation to adjusting the boundaries to maximise their vote and to make it harder, more biased and more difficult, for the will of the people to be expressed. Our aim is that the will of the people be properly expressed. We want the candidates who get just over 50 per cent of the votes to get just over 50 per cent of the seats. The Labor Party members are experts at the gerrymander, and one vote one value will not solve that problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make only a few points in this debate, and I hope to be able to finish before we adjourn this evening. We have heard a lot of nonsense this evening from senators on both sides of the chamber. I refer first to the point that was made by Senator Michael Baume, and made earlier by Senator Stone, that somehow or other the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters in relation to one vote one value had been brought up by the Labor Party because it is in trouble. The history of the development of this legislation goes back to the Whitlam years. Senator Macklin has introduced several Bills since 1985, and the Committee has now deliberated on his 1987 Bill. The report that we are now considering deals with that proposal. No-one could in any way maintain that for all that time either the Labor Party or the Liberal Party has been in the ascendancy.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Schacht, Senator Michael Baume and Senator Stone have argued a great deal about the impossibility of equal size electorates returning candidates for the party selected by the majority of the people. I would simply observe that unless we had multi-member electorates and proportional representation there is no way in which one could guarantee that result, as it is possible to show with quite simple mathematics that with single member electorates we need only a majority of people in a majority of the seats plus one-and that might be only 25 per cent of the overall electorate-or that number of people which is equal to the number of electors plus one, and that number might fall a great deal short of 50 per cent.

I note in passing that, interestingly, the present Federal Government is proposing a method of proportional representation in the Australian Capital Territory, with the d'Hondt voting system, which in fact would involve a list system of election and prevent the electors in this Territory from electing the candidates directly, that is, by putting a number opposite the name of a candidate.

Senator Stone also went on a great deal about the role of the High Court. I would point out to him that it was the minority report-that which came substantially from members of his own Party-that made the following point:

. . . the Commonwealth Constitution will inevitably result in the High Court becoming involved in disputes over these issues. These disputes are invariably Party political in character. This will politicise the Court.

That point was actually made by members of his own Party, in their minority report, and so I am not too sure exactly what point Senator Stone was trying to make in relation to the court becoming politicised. As to Senator Michael Baume's recent tirade, which went on for some 10 or 15 minutes, regarding the inequality between the States, one need only look at the second last table in the supplementary paper to see that in South Australia, in February 1988, the lowest enrolment was 16,909 and that the highest was 24,604-which is roughly a 50 per cent difference-whereas in Queensland the lowest enrolment was 8,256 and the highest was 25,398. That indicates the very gross difference which occurs between Queensland and South Australia in relation to the one vote one value system, which is the point of this report.

Several speakers earlier indicated that I had not written a minority report. The reason I did not do so is that the majority report was substantially in line with the wishes that Senator Macklin had expressed. I think he has made the point himself that in relation to the words `as near as practicable' he was prepared to see those words go in support of the 10 per cent criterion.

I make two final points. First, there is substantial legal opinion that the States of Australia do not have any existence separate from the Commonwealth at all. Indeed, the States were not States as such before Federation; they were colonies and they came into existence as States at Federation. That legal opinion would hold that the Commonwealth has full powers to assume any matter that it likes and that it is only the residual powers that lie with the States.

My final point is that this matter is primarily about a referendum, about going to the people and ascertaining the will of the people on this matter. For anyone to suggest that the proposal is steamrolling the Australian public or a particular State or that it is jackbooting them on this matter, which is one of the terms that have been used, is absolutely ridiculous. The order of democratic process involves surely the whole of the people, then the Parliament, then the Government and then the Executive. Of course, the most democratic body that one can refer to is the people. This referendum is to take the matter to the people and to ask them to decide. Surely there is nothing undemocratic about that process.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) The Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions has advised that the information sought by the honourable senator would require the manual examination of all relevant files for the past five years. The Deputy Directors of Public Prosecutions in Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne and Perth, and the Directors of Legal Services in Darwin and Adelaide do not maintain statistical records from which this information could be extracted.

The information provided by the Deputy Director of Public Prosecutions in the Australian Capital Territory does not distinguish between remandees held in respect of federal offences and those held in respect of Territory offences. It does not, therefore, assist in answering the honourable senator's question. However, so far as the Australian Capital Territory is concerned, the Deputy Director of Public Prosecutions has advised that as at 29 January 1988 only one person charged with a federal offence was on remand in custody.

The Director of Legal Services in Hobart has advised that no person charged with a federal offence has been remanded in custody in Tasmania during the last 5 years. With respect to Tasmania, the answers are: (1) 0 days, (2) 0 days, (3) Not applicable (4) Not applicable.

The monthly publication of the Australian Institute of Criminology entitled Australian Prison Trends provides statistics on a jurisdiction by jurisdiction basis for the number of prisoners on remand whether awaiting trial on sentence; the percentage of the prison population on remand; and the remand rate for the adult population. While these statistics do not identify those prisoners on remand in respect of federal offences, this publication may be of general interest to the honourable senator.
(5) The Director of Public Prosecutions has advised that adult persons on remand in custody for federal offences are held in the following State and Territory institutions.

New South Wales-Federal offenders on remand in the Sydney area are usually held at the Metropolitan Remand Centre, Long Bay, although there is now a regular practice of holding some of these prisoners on remand at Parramatta Gaol. Elsewhere in New South Wales the practice is to hold prisoners on remand at the closest gaol (for example, Maitland, Goulburn, or Parramatta). However, the New South Wales Department of Corrective Services can transfer prisoners being held on remand to other prisons.
Northern Territory-Berrimah Gaol (Darwin), Alice Springs Gaol.
Queensland-Brisbane Prison Complex (South-East Queensland). Rockhampton Prison (Central Queensland). Townsville Prison (North and Far North Queensland).
South Australia-Adelaide Remand Centre (Adelaide). Yatala Labour Prison (Adelaide). Port Augusta Gaol (Port Augusta). Mount Gambier Gaol (Mount Gambier).
Western Australia-C W Campbell Remand Centre, Canning Vale (Perth).

The Western Australian Department of Corrective Services has advised that all regional prisons have remand facilities. A federal offender arrested in a country area is likely to be remanded in the nearest country prison or remand centre.

(6) The Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions has been unable to provide this figure, except in relation to Tasmania where the Deputy Director of Public Prosecutions has advised that no person charged with a federal offence has been remanded in custody during the last 5 years.

(7) In the Australian Capital Territory, the daily average number of persons detained at the Belconnen Remand Centre over the 12 months to 31 December 1987 was 15. That figure includes federal, Australian Capital Territory and joint offenders. As the other institutions identified in answer to sub-question (5) are State and Northern Territory institutions, this is a matter for the State and Northern Territory authorities. The Attorney-General's Department does not have a record of this information.

(8) In his Annual Report for 1986-87, the Director of Public Prosecutions has indicated that the delay in bringing persons charged with federal offences to trial in New South Wales is a matter of concern. I refer the honourable senator to pages 99-100 of that Report.

(9) In his Annual Report for 1986-87, the Director of Public Prosecutions attributes the delays in New South Wales to the unavailability of courts and judicial officers; the length of hearings, particularly in drug importation and major fraud cases; and delays in the preparation of transcripts. The Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions has also advised that defence applications for adjournment are a further source of delay in particular cases. In his Annual Report for 1986-87, the Director of Public Prosecutions points out that where the trial is likely to be delayed, judicial officers are more likely to grant bail to the accused. I refer the honourable senator once again to pages 99-100 of the Report.

(10) Where delays in bringing persons accused of federal offences to trial occur as a result of the unavailability of courts, judicial officers or transcripts, these are matters for the State and Northern Territory Governments. In his Annual Report for 1986-87, the Director of Public Prosecutions indicates action taken by his Office to relieve the delays experienced in New South Wales in particular. I refer the honourable senator to page 100 of the Report where the Director states that `court rooms' have been provided at Westfield Towers and the American Express Building in Sydney, and that his Office has arranged for the preparation of unofficial transcripts from tape recorded evidence so that matters can proceed more expeditiously.

(4) How does this liability compare with that imposed on normal commercial air travel.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The majority of travel by departmental officers when on official duty, both domestic and international, is by commercial carrier. However, some officers are required to travel by departmental aircraft a) as part of their duties e.g. staff engaged in the operation of the aircraft, pilots who are required to maintain proficiency ratings, and b) occasionally some staff travelling on duty where it is considered the most economical mode of travel.

(2) Yes. Departmental aircraft are maintained and operated at the same technical standard as commercial aircraft. Passenger comfort and in-flight service, while considered adequate, are not of the same standard offered by the commercial operators given that the primary function of these aircraft is to calibrate navigational aids.

(3) The maximum liability of the Commonwealth in respect of any one staff member for death or injury resulting from an accident while on duty is $57780 as provided by the Compensation (Australian Government Employees) Act 1976. This may be overridden in relation to an accident involving departmental aircraft by the Air Accidents (Commonwealth Government Liability) Act 1963 which imposes a maximum liability of $100,000 (for interstate travel-the respective States have similar legislation in place for intrastate travel).

(4) This liability is similar to that imposed on normal commercial air travel by the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959 which also provides maximum liability of $100,000 in the event of death or injury to a passenger.
